site_title: From Abenomics to the State Secrets Act
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

From Abenomics to the State Secrets Act

Territorial disputes, diving yen among highlights for 2013

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THIS has been a year of transition for Japan, one which could see the nation escape from 15 years of deflation and stagnation and also set out along the road to developing a more open economy, one able to interact more dynamically with the rest of the Asia-Pacific region and the world.

But equally it has been a year when Japan's relations with its North-east Asian neighbours, especially China, have deteriorated badly to the point where even some kind of military confrontation has become thinkable and where Japan's post-war democratic freedoms have been challenged.

The world at large has been far more aware of the first of these two developments than the second. The emergence of "Abenomics" has attracted far more attention internationally than has Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's rather reactionary and nationalistic brand of politics.

Abenomics, a set of policy prescriptions involving huge fiscal and monetary stimulus to the Japanese economy followed (in theory at least) by fundamental structural reforms, are not the invention of Mr Abe himself. He is first and last a politician and idealogue, not an economist.

A team of academic and other advisers are the true architects of Abenomics. But in this as in other areas, the prime minister has encouraged a kind of personality cult that makes him appear as a strong leader able to give direction to a nation in need of salvation.

Some see Abenomics as a means to an end - a means to gain and retain political popularity while Mr Abe begins to implement a far more radical agenda. But the notion of a Japan that regains its erstwhile economic vigour and vitality is also very appealing for Mr Abe.

To understand the reactionary mood that has swept through Japan this year, it is necessary to see things in the context of the loss of economic and political confidence that has overtaken the country in the past 20 or so years.

The trauma of the bubble economy's collapse two decades ago lingered long and even though the bad debt mountain it left behind has long been cleared, an overly tight monetary policy by a once timid central bank choked off any sign of recovery and plunged the economy into deflation.

A rising China pushed Japan into third place behind the US (and China) in world economic league tables, and then came the triple disaster of a mega earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis in March 2011 - all capped by a stream of ineffective "revolving door" prime ministers.

Despite his own short-lived and rather ineffective tenure as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and prime minister in 2006, Mr Abe somehow managed to become a lightning rod for conducting energy and anger (especially from the right wing of the LDP) into political action.

The LDP did not so much "sweep to power" in Lower House election late last year as ride upon the failure of voters to turn out for what they saw as ineffective and short-term Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ)-led administrations. Apathy was rife among voters at large.

Former DPJ voters again stayed away in droves from the Upper House election in mid-year 2013 and the LDP was able to consolidate its hold on power to what political commentators saw as an alarming extent. History may show that such alarm was well founded, judging from recent developments.

On the Abenomics front, things have gone quite well since the appointment of former Asian Development Bank president Haruhiko Kuroda as governor of the Bank of Japan. He has pledged to turn deflation into 2 per cent annual inflation within two years and is making progress towards that goal.

The yen has plunged with Mr Kuroda's willingness to throw money at the deflation problem while corporate profits - in the export sector at least - have soared and Tokyo stocks along with them. Property prices are rising and there are signs of returning business confidence.

Economic growth, meanwhile, has improved to the point where the Asian Development Bank is predicting 1.7 per cent real GDP growth for this year, slowing to around one per cent in 2014 in the light of a proposed hike in the national consumption tax.

Growth is being boosted by not only monetary but also fiscal stimulus, a risky strategy for Japan where government debt is already double the size of the nation's economy and where Tokyo is under strong external pressure to put its fiscal house in order to avoid a possible fiscal crisis.

But the big question mark hanging over Abenomics is whether Mr Abe can deliver on his pledge to implement sweeping structural reforms that would change employment practices, de-regulate the economy and open up its more protected sectors.

So far, there is little apparent progress on this front and Mr Abe seems to be relying on experimenting with reforms within the narrow and politically safe confines of special deregulation zones, while also exposing Japan to competition via Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) membership.

While economists may differ over the merits or demerits of Abenomics, the subject is relatively uncontroversial compared with the considerable ruckus that Mr Abe has created by his decisions to take Japan down new paths in terms of its security and diplomatic policies.

In pursuit of what he claims is a process of turning Japan into a "normal" nation, he has created a new National Security Council, ordered a beefing up of military spending and rammed through a new State Secrets Act which is seen as a threat to democratic freedom in Japan.

All this is taking place against the background of a proposed revision in the country's "pacifist" postwar constitution which could see the nation abandon its self-imposed ban on collective self-defence and also see Japan projecting military power well beyond its own shores in time.

Meanwhile, territorial disputes have flared with China and South Korea to the point where observers fear a possible confrontation between Japanese and Chinese maritime vessels or aircraft engaged in a dangerous daily cat-and-mouse game of shadowing each other's movements.

Mr Abe's high popularity with voters during most of this year has taken a knock with the controversy that has erupted over the Secrets Act and and some voters have begun to question their own wisdom in awarding the LDP an almost absolute hold on power for the next few years.

MREK manages 2 Reits with assets worth 588b won

Mon, Dec 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

ARA Asset Management will be acquiring South Korea's real estate company Macquarie Real Estate Korea (MREK) for an undisclosed sum.

MREK, based in Seoul, is a manager of two privately held Korean real estate investment trusts (K-Reits) with combined assets worth 588.4 billion won (S$702 million).

As part of the conditional sale and purchase agreement, ARA will acquire a 10.02 per cent equity interest in one of the K-Reits, co-investing alongside one of Korea's largest pension funds, which is also the sole investor in the second K-Reit.

ARA also announced the incorporation of ARA Korea (Holdings) - a wholly-owned subsidiary that will manage its investment holdings in South Korea.

"As we expand our geographical footprint, the acquisition of this platform adds to ARA's current Reits platform and bolsters ARA's Reit management presence in the Asia-Pacific region," said ARA group chief executive officer (CEO) John Lim.

"In addition to Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia and China, this acquisition has allowed ARA to gain a foothold in South Korea, enabling the group to capitalise on the tremendous real estate opportunities in Asia's fourth largest economy by GDP," he added.

ARA's assets under management stood at S$23.4 billion as at Sept 30.

In November, the fund management company posted a 2 per cent rise to S$20 million in third-quarter net profit attributable to equity-holders, on the back of higher Reit management fees.

And in October, ARA formed a strategic alliance with investment holding company The Straits Trading Company, where the latter bought a 20.1 per cent stake in ARA for S$294.4 million, making Straits Trading ARA's largest shareholder, followed by its CEO Mr Lim and Cheung Kong Holdings.

ARA's shares fell 0.27 per cent yesterday to end trading at S$1.845.

[TOULOUSE] Air France- KLM Group has received a firm offer for unprofitable regional operator CityJet from German turnaround specialist Intro Aviation GmbH as Europe's biggest airline seeks to streamline short-haul operations.

The planned sale of the No 1 carrier at London City airport should close in the first quarter of 2014, Paris- based Air France said in a statement last Friday. The offer price for a deal that includes VLM Airlines of Belgium was not disclosed.

The transaction will include an agreement "for ongoing commercial cooperation" between the companies, Air France said, adding that labour groups will be consulted.

Air France offered City- Jet for sale in September 2012 as part of a revamp aimed at ending European losses. Intro, founded by retail entrepreneur Hans-Rudolf Woehrl, is taking on a carrier with a fleet of 38 BAE Systems Plc Avro RJ85 jets and Fokker 50 turboprops able to serve London City's short runway.

In preparation for a change of ownership, City- Jet had already begun operating its own revenue system, CEO Christine Ourmieres said in an interview last month.

Intro was founded in 1973 by Mr Woehrl, who ran Nuremburg-based NFD before selling the carrier to Eurowings in 1992, according to the Reichenschwand- based company's website.

Mr Woehrl became CEO of Deutsche BA in 2003 after buying the unit for 1 euro from British Airways, which had hired him to shut it down. The operation was refocused on the high-frequency business travel market and sold to Air Berlin Plc in 2006.

CityJet, which has its offices in Dublin, had a 6.2 million euro (S$10.7 million) operating loss for the nine months through December 2011 on sales of 238 million euros, according to its most recent filing with the Irish companies office.- Bloomberg

site_title: A made-in-S'pore app that encrypts on the fly
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A made-in-S'pore app that encrypts on the fly

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] What started out as a search for an easy-to-use and affordable encryption tool eventually led two good friends to start a security business in Singapore.

Banker and financier Michael Tse needed a secure way to distribute medical reports to more than 100 doctors using the Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Centre, a medical facility he had set up in Hong Kong. Such reports were being distributed by courier to the doctors who were not stationed in the facility, and some got lost on the way.

Finding point-to-point encryption solutions too expensive then, he turned to his Singaporean friend Kwok-Yan Lam, who has been teaching security in universities since 1990, for help. His request was that the solution had to be robust for the enterprise, yet simple enough for the consumer to use.

The result was a Singapore-developed application that allows users to encrypt information easily on the fly by saving it in a password-protected folder.

Called Soda, which stands for Safe of Data App, it acts as a "digital safe" in which encrypted files are organised into folders that can only be read by their intended users.

Soda comes with a cross-platform capability, which means that data such as photos, videos and documents can be encrypted using an Android phone, saved to the cloud, then downloaded and decrypted even in an iPhone, iPad or PC. The file is automatically decrypted when opened in the Soda folder.

"Encryption is quite easy to do nowadays - there is a lot of freeware. The difficult part is how to do it in such a way that people use it easily without having to deal with technical interfaces," said Professor Lam, who is an exco member of the Singapore Association of Information Security Professionals and an Adjunct Professor at the National University of Singapore. He has served as chief security consultant and architect for many local and regional projects on e-commerce and border control systems.

Prof Lam noted that most users try to avoid encryption as it is too difficult to use. Yet mobile devices, which are goldmines of information due to the myriad personal and work-related activities that they are used for, can be easy targets for cyber criminals.

To ensure a high level of security even for enterprise users, Soda was built on the same proven cryptography platform (certified to The National Institute of Standards and Technology's Federal Information Processing Standards) used by banks and governments.

The application is free for download in the iOS App Store and Android Google Play Store.

"People are not aware, or even if they are aware, they have no easy tool to protect their data. That is why the basic version is free of charge - we wanted to start something to educate people about personal privacy protection," said Prof Lam.

A premium version, which allows individual users or small-sized businesses to enjoy unlimited sending of encrypted data, costs just US$4.99 per user a year.

There is also a corporate version - Soda Enterprise - that is designed to work seamlessly with existing corporate IT infrastructure and offers more advanced features such as secure P2P sharing of confidential files, as well as secure file exchange and group messaging.

"To enterprises, Soda is not only an app but a software platform that supports mobile and cloud applications requiring strong privacy and confidentiality protection," said Mr Tse.

Piloted among 300 users in Asia a year ago, the security application has been downloaded almost 1,000 times by users not just in Asia but also in the US and Europe. Mr Tse expects 500,000 downloads by the end of 2014.

Soda has been used by the Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Centre to encrypt and send screening results to doctors since January.

To promote the software, the duo set up Soda Pte Ltd in Singapore in January 2012.

The start-up, which employs 12 people, also has sales and marketing offices in Hong Kong and Malaysia, and plans to expand its presence in South-east Asia in the near term.

It is targeting telecommunications service providers offering cloud storage, banks that need to issue electronic statements and government agencies, among others.

In all, over $1 million have been injected into the company, and Mr Tse, who serves as its chairman, hopes to achieve 50-100 corporate sign-ups and break even by the end of 2014. Customers currently include organisations in the telecommunications and public sectors.

Singapore firms working on smart chips for IoT

An estimated 30b devices will be wirelessly connected to the Internet of Things patchwork by 2020

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] As we approach the dawn of the Internet of Things (IoT), some of Singapore's top tech firms are working on researching ways to put the island state on the global map.

The Internet of Things is a concept that refers to the set of sensors and devices out there in the world, all connected to the Web in some form or other. The concept was coined more than a decade ago, but is now starting to gather momentum because of the wireless connectivity built into more and more devices today.

Speaking at an event hosted by the Singapore Chapter of the Internet Society, CK Lim, CEO of Ascent Solutions, said that the local electronics manufacturer is currently researching a self-tuning, self-sensing RFID (radio frequency identification) chip.

The project is underway in a collaboration with US RFID sensor maker RF Micron with the objective of developing a chip that can sense properties in its surroundings, and deliver data to connected devices.

The chip can be embedded in everyday devices. Mr Lim said that, for example, the chip can be placed in adult diapers, to alert caretakers if it is soiled, without the need and hassle of manually checking.

This is possible today, because RFID prices have come down so dramatically in the past decade, he said. "We're getting accurate devices in the couple-of-hundred- dollars range today, where it would have cost thousands before," Mr Lim said.

NCS strategic business development director Ching Yin Sing said that the SingTel-owned IT firm has begun work with an international retailer to implement smart video sensors in its stores in four Asian cities: Singapore, Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur and Shanghai.

The client carries garments, and NCS has placed video cameras on its clothes racks. The cameras feed the image information to a central server which crunches that data, and is able to reach 96 per cent accuracy in counting the number of people moving to the rack, said Mr Ching. The camera data will also be able to tell the store which racks are popular, based on how long people hover in that area.

He also cited the example of Tesco in the UK, where the company has placed video cameras behind its point-of-sale counters at petrol stations. The cameras are able to detect the gender and approximate age of the patron, and that influences the ads shown to the customer behind the cashier based on their demographic slice.

"Cameras can do intrusion detection by detecting motion, and make up crowd-density heat maps, profile audiences and chart human traffic footfall patterns, to name some uses," Mr Ching said.

According to ABI Research, more than 30 billion devices will be wirelessly connected to the Internet of Things patchwork by 2020.

Fellow research agency Gartner has a similar estimate - 26 billion connected devices in that year, representing an almost 30-fold increase from 2009's 900 million devices.

Lack of standardisation

Gartner also estimates that product and service suppliers to this network will make up a US$300 billion market in 2020. It expects that the leading verticals pushing the development of the Internet of Things will be manufacturing, healthcare and insurance.

But while the applications continue to grow as companies discover new uses for sensors, the industry suffers from a lack of standardisation, said Mr Ching.

"There's very little work being done to get sensors connected easily," he said.

Tan Geok Leng, executive director of the Institute for Infocomm Research (I2R) at A*Star (the Agency for Science, Technology and Research), echoed this point. He said that the research institution is currently focused on helping to establish a standard communication platform between different sensors.

"Imagine if you could get traffic readings from the ERP (Electronic Road Pricing) gantries, and feed that to traffic reports. That would be a valuable source of data, but that information isn't easily obtainable right now," he said.

He noted that most applications are written and deployed in silos, in part because that allows them to deliver business objectives more quickly, since they don't need to work well with other applications.

"But in the long run, that's not efficient," he said. Data sharing could lead to powerful analytics being done across siloed applications, greatly lifting the IT industry's contribution as a whole.

"Still, it will take time to work well with others. Nobody wants to be the first," said Mr Tan.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Telstra to sell 76.4% stake in CSL for A$2b

Sale to HKT gives Telstra A$600m profit on CSL's book value

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AUSTRALIA's Telstra is selling its stake in Hong Kong mobile operator CSL in a deal that will bring in proceeds of about A$2 billion (S$2.26 billion), it said yesterday.

Telstra will sell its 76.4 per stake in CSL to HKT Ltd, netting itself a profit of about A$600 million on CSL's book value. Even so, this gain comes after previous writedowns on the asset's book value as CSL battled a brutal and competitive market over the last decade.

"Telstra invested in this business in early-2000s for gross investment of around A$4 billion and then gradually wrote it down," a Nomura Equity Research report noted yesterday.

HKT, which will buy all of CSL for a total of US$2.425 billion - 76.4 per cent from Telstra and the remaining 23.6 per cent from New World Development - is a part of the PCCW group, which is chaired by Richard Li, the son of Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing.

When the deal is completed, CSL will have come full circle. Before the turn of the millennium, PCCW had owned CSL. Over 2001 and 2002, Telstra progressively bought stakes in CSL from PCCW, eventually owning all of the former. In 2006, however, CSL and New World PCS Limited were merged in a deal that reduced Telstra's stake in CSL to 76.4 per cent.

Explaining the decision to exit the business yesterday, Telstra chief executive David Thodey said that "there are a number of dynamics in the Hong Kong mobiles market that means this is the right opportunity for Telstra to maximise our return on this successful asset".

He noted that CSL's compounded annual growth rate over the last three years stood at 9.4 per cent, calling it a "strongly performing business".

In its last financial year ended June 30, 2013, CSL took in A$1.01 billion in revenue - 17.6 per cent more than in the previous year - which accounted for about 4 per cent of total revenue. In Hong Kong dollar terms, Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation) grew by 14.9 per cent to HK$2.06 billion (S$336.6 million).

According to the Nomura report, the sale might be for the best as "the market is competitive (five players) and becoming saturated, too, so this is a good outcome, we think".

The market also welcomed the move yesterday, with Telstra's counter gaining nine Australian cents or 1.76 per cent to A$5.20 in trading.

Telstra kept mum on how it would use the proceeds from the sale, saying only: "Following completion, Telstra will address the net proceeds from the transaction consistent with its capital management framework."

The Nomura report said: "More dividends is one possibility, but we understand there is no additional tax paid on this sale due to accumulated losses, hence the franking balance may not change. The preference of Telstra management and board is to pay fully franked dividends.

"Telstra is still open to pursuing other opportunities, too - so the proceeds may be deployed/ preserved for other investments as well."

Telstra's involvement elsewhere in the region continues. Recently, it upped its stake in Autohome Inc, an online portal for automobile buyers in China, and listed it on the New York Stock Exchange. Its investment in Autohome Inc is now valued at US$1.9 billion.

Over the last 18 months, the telco also entered into two new submarine cable investments and opened a new data centre in Singapore, among other things.

Yesterday, Telstra's Mr Thodey said that his team will focus on "refining and enhancing our strategy across Asia".

Regulatory approval of the sale is expected to take around 90 days and the deal is estimated to be finalised by the first quarter of 2014, according to media reports.

site_title: Eurozone recovering, but the jury's still out
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Eurozone recovering, but the jury's still out

'Lost decade' feared as GDP is still 3% below 2008 levels

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BATTERED by continual crises, eurozone bond and stock markets surprised doomsayers and performed far better than expected. The region's economy, however, has experienced only a gingerly revival so far, with Germany the leader, but France a growing problem.

The only major scare in 2013 came from events on the small island of Cyprus, but predictions that the crisis would envelop Greece and other weak nations in the eurozone proved to be wrong.

At the beginning of the year, the outlook was dire. Eurostat, the European Union's statistics office, reported that the eurozone economy had plunged in the final quarter of 2012. Gross domestic product of the region had fallen 0.6 per cent in the fourth quarter compared with the third, and it was the fifth quarter in which the currency bloc had failed to expand. For 2012 as a whole, GDP of the eurozone contracted 0.5 per cent.

As 2013 began, GDP in Germany, Europe's largest economy, was down 0.6 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2012 compared with the previous quarter, and there were worries about declining exports and investment.

France contracted 0.3 per cent and other sizeable economies - notably Italy, Spain and the Netherlands - also shrank. Italy's GDP plummeted 0.9 per cent, Spain's downturn also deepened, and Portugal's GDP slid 1.8 per cent.

The dismal performance - which was accompanied by a further rise in already high unemployment of 10.7 per cent or some 26 million - led to protests and government changes, notably in Italy and Greece. Economists predicted that at best there would be a gingerly revival in 2013.

In March, a botched Cyprus bailout deal precipitated sharp European and global stockmarket declines as investors feared a run on the island's banks and Greek and other financial institutions that were exposed to a possible default.

In an adjusted agreement, international lenders were forced to accept the closure of a major Cypriot bank, Laiki, and the seizure of savings from large depositors to recapitalise a second troubled lender, Bank of Cyprus.

Both banks had suffered huge losses from a write-down in the value of Greek government bonds, an arrangement brokered by EU leaders in late 2011 to make Greece's debts more manageable.

At the time, Mohamed El-Erian, chief executive of Pimco, the world's largest bond investor, commented that the Cyprus bailout could "well undermine the recent tranquil behaviour of depositors and creditors in other vulnerable European economies - in particular Greece, Italy, Portugal and Spain". Indeed, as markets tumbled, the euro sank to around 1.28 against the US dollar.

The euro and European stock and bond markets rallied after the last-minute rescue averted a potential Cypriot exit from the eurozone, a financial meltdown, massive devaluation and rampant inflation. Cypriot President Nicos Anastasiades accepted the new terms from the "Troika" comprising the European Union, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the European Central Bank (ECB) for a loan of 10 billion euros, and that eventually reduced tensions.

Cyprus proved to be a hiccup as once again markets took the lead from ECB president Mario Draghi who in the late summer of 2012 had promised to do "whatever it takes" within the central bank's mandate to preserve the euro.

The market assumed the ECB would be buying dud bonds of zombie banks and indebted Southern European nations. Instead, Mr Draghi's "jawboning" improved sentiment and the euro recovered, and bond and equity markets began to take off, baffling even the most bullish forecasters.

Since its mid-year low point, the euro has risen by 7 per cent, and sterling - boosted by rising UK property prices and higher consumption and growth - by 10 per cent. Greece and Ireland have been the best performing European stock markets, beating Germany and the UK - both the best performing economies, by a wide margin.

Also, bond yields of the so-called "Club Med" nations have fallen sharply as banks rather than the ECB have purchased the bonds.

This improvement helped lift growth of the average of the 28 European Union economies to 0.1 per cent in the third quarter, but sadly the eurozone still contracted 0.4 per cent. The UK has been the star economy growing 1.5 per cent in the September quarter compared with the same period in 2012, after a rise of 1.3 per cent in Q2. Germany's growth was 0.6 per cent, but France's was only 0.2 per cent. Italy, Spain and Portugal contracted, and Greece and Cyprus remained in deep recession.

Ruth Lea, economic adviser at Arbuthnot Banking Group, contends that the eurozone will "muddle through for the foreseeable future" without any cataclysmic policy change.

On Dec 15, Ireland formally exited its rescue plan, after three years of austerity. Spain has announced that, following Ireland's lead, it intends to exit its bank bailout plan in January without seeking a precautionary credit line.

The "Grand Coalition" government, under Chancellor Angela Merkel, has agreed that Germany should still be "tough on austerity". But that is at a severe price. The eurozone's GDP is still 3 per cent below pre-financial crisis 2008 levels, and a recent study of the International Institute for Strategic Studies maintains that it faces a lost decade.

site_title: Protesters gather again to demand Yingluck resign
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Protesters gather again to demand Yingluck resign

Feb election now hangs in the balance with the Democrat Party boycotting it

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] Tens of thousands of anti-government demonstrators once again massed at several sites in Thailand's capital yesterday in a bid to topple Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, before a now uncertain February election which the main opposition party will boycott.

Ms Yingluck has called a snap poll for Feb 2 to try to cool tensions and renew her mandate, but protesters are rejecting any election until the implementation of vague reforms ostensibly aimed at weakening the influence of the Shinawatra family.

The weeks-long political deadlock became more uncertain on Saturday when the opposition Democrat Party, Thailand's oldest, announced it would boycott the election, saying that the democratic system had failed Thais.

The boycott adds to concern that powerful forces allied with the opposition would try to scuttle an election that is otherwise likely to return Ms Yingluck's Puea Thai Party to power, and perpetuate the influence of her self-exiled brother, former premier Thaksin Shinawatra.

Chanting "Yingluck, get out", thousands of whistle-blowing protesters gathered at locations around the city and set up stages in at least four places, bringing traffic to a halt at three main intersections and in two commercial districts.

Up to 1,000 protesters surrounded Ms Yingluck's house and demanded she quit. Ms Yingluck, now caretaker premier, is not in Bangkok and has been visiting the north-east, her party's stronghold.

The protest movement's main leader, Suthep Thaugsuban, a former Democrat heavyweight, wants a suspension of democracy and the installation of an appointed "people's council". "I don't know what Yingluck is thinking. But, what I know for sure now is that all civil servants, the army, the police have realised all Thai people are rising up against the government," Mr Suthep told Blue Sky, an anti-government cable television station.

Mr Suthep has earned a reputation for overstated rhetoric during fiery nightly speeches, where he has told police and civil servants to report to him, promised to retire to the beach and issued deadlines to army leaders to meet him to discuss ousting Ms Yingluck.

Ms Yingluck and Thaksin remain hugely popular in the north and north-east, but Mr Suthep's movement is backed by a powerful minority - Bangkok's middle class, bureaucrats, conservative elites and top army generals.

Thaksin's mainly rural-based supporters see him as a benevolent billionaire committed to raising their living standards, but his enemies call him an authoritarian crony capitalist who exploited the poor and abused his power by helping wealthy business friends and family.

The protests enjoy big support from Bangkok and though the size of the crowd often dwindles, Mr Suthep has managed to mobilise more than 100,000 on some marches.

The Election Commission on Friday ruled out postponing the vote, having earlier said that it was concerned the polls could be marred by violence.

Separately, more than 20 people were wounded when a car bomb went off near a hotel in the Sadao district of Songkhla province.

National Security Council chief Paradorn Pattanatabut told AFP the culprits may have been linked to the Thai rebellion in the south, as peace talks faltered.

"A second theory is it was related to the domestic political situation - to discredit the government," he added. - Reuters, AFP

site_title: Expedia trims backend code to fly higher
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Expedia trims backend code to fly higher

Its flight-booking application is much more flexible today than it was 3 years ago

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Flight booking giant Expedia is one of the older travel websites, and over the past three years, it has gone through an extensive diet on its backend code so that it can fight with leaner start-ups that have come on the scene.

The Nasdaq-listed firm brought in revenues of US$4 billion in 2012, and employs over 12,000 globally across its various Web properties like Hotels.com and Hotwire.com.

The Expedia property itself specialises in providing a meta-search across airline carriers and aggregates flights so that users can easily compare prices.

In recent years, however, the travel space has seen the entrance of players like Wego, Webjet, Skyscanner and Farecompare, which provide similar meta-search services. Many of these sites make money by charging a referral fee for bookings directed from their sites.

In an interview with BizIT, Expedia's technical director for Southeast Asia, Lorin Kobashigawa-Bates, said the company's flight- booking application is much more flexible today than it was three years ago.

"Expedia is a 15-year- old company, and so we have code that is just as old. Back then, the code wasn't designed to be flexible, and a lot of it is written from scratch. So when you hire someone off the street, there is a long learning curve for them," he explained.

Over the past three years, Expedia has invested heavily in its tech team and in modernising its Web code. This has helped accelerate the time-to-market for new features and services on the website, in order to stay fresh in light of growing competition.

"Almost our entire app has been rewritten over the past few years. We emphasised speed-to-market, and now huge chunks of our development process are automated," the technical director said. This speed-to-market is important because the company wants to tap customer feedback as soon as possible, so that it can refine its app faster, he added.

"The process of overhauling was a bit rough at first, and these investments were a huge spend in the IT department," he said.

But crossing that initial hump has paid off, because the Expedia team is able to much more quickly build mobile products and reuse large components of its Web kit for mobile platforms, he said.

This has been timely, because the mobile space has taken off in a big way in the past few years. "The mobile space is a whole new market that wasn't there before, such as last-minute hotel bookings which are made on the go," he said.

As a result, the volume of deals targeted at mobile users continues to grow, he said.

And in Southeast Asia, where credit card penetration and desktop online penetration remains low, the mobile provides a gateway to a new market of mobile- first users, he noted.

Mr Kobashigawa-Bates heads software development for Expedia.com Asia-Pacific, as well as Air- AsiaGo.com. AirAsiaGo is the portal that was formed through a partnership with Malaysian low-cost carrier AirAsia. The two companies also have an exclusive third-party arrangement to distribute AirAsia's flights only through Expedia.

Such arrangements are possible because of Expedia's size and clout in the market, which help it stay ahead of the smaller competition, he said.

"While there has been an explosion in the number of meta-searchers out there, it's harder to re-create an Expedia because we have so many tight supplier relationships," he said.

But one of the challenges facing the tech team in trying to be aggressive in Asia is that all of Expedia's data centres are in the US. The team decided to launch on Amazon Web Services (AWS), which has a data centre in Singapore, in order for its site to load faster because it's being served out of a geographically nearer data centre to customers.

"Speed of loading really matters. We deal with live, on-the-minute price fluctuations," and the company relies on regional hosting partners to keep its website performance snappy, Mr Kobashigawa-Bates said.

His team for Southeast Asia is spread out over the region, with 12 developers in Singapore, eight in Gurgaon, India, and 18 in Shenzhen, China. The team's main function is to customise the company's products for the Asian market.

The team is now working on bringing the company's Scratchpad product to Asia, scheduled for next year.

Scratchpad is a feature on Expedia that it launched just late this year. It allows users to save hotels and flights onto one page, so that they can come back and review their research done on prices.

"It sounds simple, but a lot of work on the backend needs to be done, because the Scratchpad remembers your searches, and live-updates prices. We need to present that data in a rapid and interactive manner, which requires a lot of muscle on backend servers," he said, noting again the company's reliance on the AWS cloud for that performance boost.

site_title: Shedding light on fountain of youth
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Shedding light on fountain of youth

US dermatologist Patrick Bitter, who discovered Intense Pulsed Light therapy for ageing skin, develops the next generation of light treatment called BBL Forever Young. By Jaime Ee

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

MAYBE people who say money can't buy happiness never got what they paid for? You'd be unhappy too, if you spent hundreds or even thousands on beauty products and regimes promising to return your ageing skin to its 20-something collagen-enriched self, only to be reminded once again that this is how the beauty industry makes its money - by selling hope in a jar with minimal results.

But what if someone came up to you and said that they could not only give you youthful skin but skin that continues to get younger with regular treatments? Do you dismiss him as just another snake oil salesman, or would you be vain enough to at least hear him out?

In this case, the person in question - Patrick Bitter - does make a rather convincing case. For one, the California-based dermatologist made his name as the founder of the IPL (intense pulsed light) photo-facial which uses the light-based therapy to remove scars and rejuvenate the skin. The popular method was first introduced in Singapore in 2000 but of late, Dr Bitter has progressed beyond IPL to a newer technology called BroadBand Light, for which he was recently in town for.

The technology comes from a machine built by the Palo Alto company Sciton, which approached Dr Bitter seven years ago to develop a technique for anti-ageing treatments. Essentially a more powerful IPL machine, it uses a broader spectrum of both infrared and visible light to penetrate the skin layers, which is supposed to be more effective than IPL's single wavelength. The real kicker, though, is that this new therapy, aptly named BBL Forever Young, goes beyond the skin surface, stimulating changes at the molecular level and literally making old skin cells young again.

"I did a study with the dermatology department at Stanford University which was designed to look at ageing cells and the expression of the genes," explains Dr Bitter, who published the results of the study in the Journal of Investigative Dermatology. "We know there's a difference between old and young skin cells in terms of how the genes are read. Essentially, this technology can, with no downtime, change old skin cells and make them look like young skin cells. Regular treatment helps to keep these old skin cells young, and the results we have had of patients over the years is that they look like they have hardly aged at all."

New discovery

In fact, this is a relatively new discovery that people aren't really aware of, says Dr Bitter. BBL technology has been around for around seven years but while they knew about its effectiveness in rejuvenating the skin, "we didn't know that if you did it regularly, it could slow down and even stop ageing".

But put any Benjamin Button fantasies out of your head, because a 50-year-old is not going to look 25 after a few years of BBL treatments. Essentially, it makes your skin look brighter and clearer "and you will look better than other people your age", says Dr Bitter, 58, a regular user who boasts the tight skin of a 40-something.

On whether BBL can replace other non-invasive therapies such as, say, Ulthera or Thermage which purports to tighten skin and lift sagging jowls, Dr Bitter says: "If you start at middle age when you've got some sagginess in the skin, BBL can help a little bit but you might still want to consider other treatments designed to tighten skin, or consider a (surgical) facelift. But if you start younger in your 30s or even early 40s and do regular treatments, your skin will stay tighter than other people your age who don't do it."

Where BBL differs from other treatments is that they use different technologies such as radio frequency or ultrasound and "they are all designed to stimulate collagen and tighten skin, but they don't take old skin cells and make them young again," says Dr Bitter.

In Singapore, BBL Forever Young has been available for almost a year, with plastic surgeon Lee Shu Jin being one of the early converts. Dr Lee, who runs her own practice in Mount Elizabeth Medical Centre, says that she does a combination of BBL and another modality called Skin Tight - which uses the same machine - to tighten sagging skin as well as brighten it. "For issues like brown spots, redness, fine lines and wrinkles, most people will see their skin looking better within a week," she says.

Looking brighter

While repeat treatments are required, she reckons that one session that combines BBL and Skin Tight still works out to about a quarter of the price of say, Thermage. One session of BBL alone is priced around $350 to $400 and it takes roughly three to four monthly sessions to see any real effects. The treatment itself is a breeze, as topical anaesthetic cream is applied so you don't feel anything while the probes are run across your face. There's a bit of heat when the probes approach more sensitive areas around the eyes, but there's no painful rubber band snapping hits that you get with regular IPL. Your face looks a little brighter immediately and it feels tighter for a few days but it's largely a temporary effect.

It will take time to see the difference - at least four monthly treatments and then two to three a year for maintenance. But Dr Lee has seen clients coming in every month, so if money is no issue, then happiness - "and the closest we've come to a fountain of youth" - is just a credit card signature away.

site_title: Xi Jinping cements hold on power
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Xi Jinping cements hold on power

He comes across as an authoritarian, a political conservative, an economics reformist

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Beijing

A LITTLE more than a year ago, analysts, political observers and high-ranking officials could do little more than guess who China's new leader was and where he would lead the world's second largest economy. Little was known of his political views or agenda.

One year on, Xi Jinping, who comes across as much more affable than his stern predecessor, has given few clues about his personality, but we have a much clearer picture of where he is taking China.

Barely after stepping into his new shoes, he launched a vast anti-corruption campaign to officially purge the party of dishonest elements and committed to deliver the "China dream", later changed to "Chinese dream", a vague slogan that holds the promise of a rejuvenated nation. He has also never missed an occasion at home or abroad to declare the need for economic reform - but any political change is clearly not on the agenda.

When he came to power, the Communist Party seemed torn by internal wars, a pending Bo Xilai trial and rumours about a potential coup. Since then, Mr Xi has consolidated his power and left little doubt as to who is in charge. Analysts call him the most powerful leader since Deng Xiaoping. His main achievement is to have reaffirmed the supremacy of the Communist Party with him at the helm.

He is the head of state and the military. At the Party Plenum in mid-November, two new bodies - the National Security Council and a special group to oversee reform - were created. Both are likely to fall into his hands or go to a close ally. For the moment, his premier, Li Keqiang, who was, going by tradition, to run daily operations and frame economic policies, has taken a back seat.

Many say the reason Mr Xi has accumulated so much power is to keep the upper hand and to be able to pass reforms, many of which will delve into the vested interests of party officials and state-owned enterprises. But what he has also made clear is that he will not tolerate dissent, whether from inside or outside the party ranks. He has been cracking down on free speech online, removing liberal academics from their college teaching posts and arresting outspoken social activists. And much of his anti-corruption campaign, all the while appealing to the public, has enabled him to place his men in key areas.

In other words, Mr Xi is seen as an authoritarian with a strong nationalist twist; a political conservative and economic reformist. Indeed, on the economic front, he has done more to shift the economic model than his predecessors in the past decade.

He is determined to reform a system that inherently creates unproductive debt, imbalances and has reached its limits. The third plenum document was implicit in granting the market a bigger role. It also tackled issues that the last team lacked courage to address: reform of the hukou or household registration, and the one child policy, among others.

The effects of Mr Xi's determination to advance on economic and social reform are already being felt. Barely one month on, new IPO rules have been drafted, a set of capital account liberalisation policy measures for the Shanghai free trade zone have been announced.

Also, an evaluation system for local governments was revamped - with energy consumption, environmental protection and food safety to be taken into account alongside GDP (gross domestic product).

The Economic Work Conference, held at the beginning of December, specifically addressed implementation of the hukou reform.

Mr Xi's bet is that by better satisfying the material needs of the Chinese people and continuing to pull out of poverty the millions still in under-urbanised poor areas, he can pass on any political change.

The word "democracy" barely comes up in the Plenum document. His anti-model is Mikhail Gorbachev, former president of the USSR, whom he had reportedly accused during a private Party meeting earlier this year of bringing the former communist bloc to the brink of collapse.

On the contrary, his rhetoric has a neo-Maoist nationalist slant. He has revived practices such as "self-criticism sessions" while invoking the Maoist "mass line" concept of getting the Party closer to the people. He has also flexed China's muscles on the international scene with the unilateral creation of a defence zone on part of the South China Sea as a sign of a more aggressive and assertive China, much to the displeasure of its neighbours.

Many Chinese scholars and intellectuals who call for more political opening raise the question of whether the current model of a one-party system is sustainable. Analysts say that he is unlikely to touch the foundations of the regime that has nurtured him and bought him to power.

"We must incessantly consolidate and perfect the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese socialist system, we must incessantly satisfy the people's daily increasing materials and cultural needs," he told the National Propaganda and Ideology Work Conference last August in a speech on how to perpetuate communist ideology.

site_title: Bank regulations leave German shipowners dry
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bank regulations leave German shipowners dry

Ship financing will be difficult in 2014 due to stricter rules

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[HAMBURG] Tighter regulation for banks will make it even harder for German shipowners to obtain loans next year, prolonging the liquidity squeeze that they have battled since 2008, the head of the VDR industry association said.

"I doubt very much that ship financing will become easier in 2014, as banks face increasing regulation and stricter capital rules," said Michael Behrendt, VDR's president, in a Dec 13 interview here.

HSH Nordbank AG, the world's largest shipping financier, Commerzbank AG and Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale have curbed or halted lending to small and mid-sized companies as bad loans swell amid the slump in the shipping industry. The banks are among about 130 European lenders whose balance sheets and assets are being tested by the European Central Bank (ECB) before it assumes the role of financial regulator at the end of next year.

The hiatus in lending has left many shipowners struggling to cover operating costs after their fleets expanded while demand slowed, sending charter rates plunging.

"Commerzbank is exiting the market, and I don't see an urge among other banks to fill that gap," said Mr Behrendt, who is also the chief executive officer of Hapag-Lloyd AG, Germany's largest container shipping line. "Companies need to find new, creative ways of financing - and we are seeing hedge funds, private equity firms and also Chinese banks surveying the market, but hesitance prevails."

Financing for German companies will only improve when the market recovers from the shipping industry slump triggered by the failure of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc in 2008, Mr Behrendt said. The glut in vessels will not ease until the end of 2014 at the earliest, he said.

"Nobody could have foreseen the cave-in that has ripped the shipping industry apart at the seams as a result of Lehman's collapse," Mr Behrendt said. "The banks haven't acted negligently, it was a viable business model until 2008."

The ECB will take over supervision of all euro-area banks next year, after a transition period in which regulators will assess the quality of banks' assets and their resilience to shocks.

Bundesbank listed shipping loans as one of three areas in German banking that are particularly vulnerable to default risk in its Financial Stability Review, published on Nov 14.

Germany's shipping industry, which operates the world's third largest merchant fleet, has so far largely been spared from insolvencies of whole shipping companies, said Mr Behrendt.

"But there were 119 insolvencies of closed-end ship funds this year, which is a dramatic increase," he said.

In the last three years, Germany has seen a total of about 400 insolvencies of KG-ships, an asset financing model specific to Germany in which individuals invest in single vessels, Mr Behrendt said.

The industry's decline is also prompting consolidation as companies seek shelter through mergers.

Hapag-Lloyd is discussing a possible combination with Cia Sud Americana de Vapores SA, Latin America's biggest container shipping line, after talks to merge with local competitor Hamburg Sued failed in March because shareholders of the companies could not agree on terms.

One example of the few alternative financing models that are emerging is a joint venture formed in September by Rickmers Group, a Hamburg-based shipping company, with funds of New York-based Apollo Global Management LLC to buy container ships with a total investment of as much as US$500 million.

Financing partnerships between shipowners are also emerging as a way to sidestep the lending squeeze.

Partners, a joint venture announced in August between Hamburg-based ER Capital Holding and Schulte Group, is seeking to buy vessels at current low prices with the aim of selling later at a profit. - Bloomberg

SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore icons

2013 saw Singapore design being truly embraced as more local designers garner global and local recognition, winning several awards in the process. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WHETHER you are an architect, industrial designer, home furnishings retailer or just a design buff, 2013 has been a busy year.

"This has been a good year. Our architects continue to produce high-quality work evident in the Singapore Institute of Architects (SIA) Architectural Design Awards and President's Design Awards," says Theodore Chan, president of SIA. "Internationally, they also continue to make their mark."

For a start, faculty housing Kent Vale at Clementi Road won MKPL Architects an award from the Royal Institute of British Architects. Local firms W Architects and CSYA won Arcasia Awards for Architecture.

On the international front, five projects by Singaporean architects won the vote of judges at the World Architecture Festival.

Jeffrey Ho, DesignSingapore Council's executive director, is excited with the bumper crop of 15 designers and designs from the various disciplines that have won big at this year's President's Design Awards. For the first time since its inception in 2006, a floral designer was named Designer of the Year. "We are also heartened to see that these design leaders are investing time and effort to groom the next generation of designers," says Mr Ho.

Singapore's industrial designers also had a good showing at the Milan Salone del Mobile, the world's largest furniture fair. Designer Melvin Ong received a confidence boost when a customer bought his side tables within five minutes of seeing them.

This year, local design studio Supermama launched Singapore Icons, a range of ceramic ware designed by Singaporeans that bear distinct Singapore icons. site_title: Taking Religare beyond India
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Taking Religare beyond India

The trust aims to expand its portfolio to other Asia-Pacific markets, says its CEO Gurpreet Dhillon, reports NISHA RAMCHANDANI

Published

Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

A YEAR into its listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), Religare Health Trust (RHT) is considering expanding its portfolio beyond India to include other Asia-Pacific markets, even as it continues to push for growth from existing assets.

"The first year was about stabilising the portfolio, about delivering everything we set out to our investors," Gurpreet Dhillon, RHT's CEO told BT in an interview. "The next year is going to be about building on that foundation, looking for growth opportunities both inside the portfolio and outside."

Mr Dhillon assumed the role of chief executive in May this year, taking over from Ravi Mehrotra, currently executive chairman, in order to separate the roles of CEO and chairman.

"We do want to, at some stage, go and diversify from Fortis and India. I think there is a case for diversification. As and when it happens, it will have to be meaningful. I don't think it makes sense for us to just buy one hospital in five different geographies. We are working on that," said Mr Dhillon, adding that its plan to grow its footprint overseas could happen within the next year.

Expanding overseas

In this respect, its preference would be to invest in more stable markets, such as Australia or Japan, to help offset the risks in emerging markets such as India.

But even as RHT is ready to look beyond India to fuel growth, it remains cognisant of the opportunities within the populous country, especially as private healthcare continues to gain traction in a nation of over one billion people.

In India, RHT's portfolio includes 13 operating assets - which typically focus on either single specialities or multiple specialities - as well as four upcoming greenfield sites in Ludhiana, Chennai, Hyderabad and Greater Noida in the coming years. As at March 31, its portfolio was valued at approximately $772 million.

India's Fortis Healthcare, probably best remembered for taking on Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional in a takeover battle for then Parkway Holdings, holds 28 per cent of the units in RHT. It also operates RHT's healthcare assets, paying RHT a combination of a base fee, as well as a variable fee which is set at 7.5 per cent of the operating revenue of a hospital. But RHT runs other services which are typically outsourced, such as outpatient services, radiology and food & beverages.

Since its listing in October last year, the business trust has added some 550 beds to its then-portfolio of about 1,700 beds. On Friday, RHT closed at 77 cents per unit, under its IPO price of 90 cents.

"What we've been working (on) with Fortis is to start with organic growth. That's low-hanging fruit for us. There's limited capital expenditure required," he points out, adding that the variable fee serves as a "huge kicker" for the trust.

Excluding the four greenfield sites, RHT could add some 1,700 hospital beds by expanding its existing assets. Including them, it could be looking at ramping the portfolio up to a total of 4,600 beds, roughly double what it is today.

Fortis, which is backed by Indian billionaires Malvinder and Shivinder Singh, has also been scaling back its international presence through divestments, which could work in RHT's favour.

"They've re-evaluated the strategy and the focus is now to grow in India," Mr Dhillon said. "That's a huge plus for RHT because future capex is going to come in India, where all our assets are today. We can actually work with Fortis to grow because we can step in on the asset heavy side, while they come in on the operations side. Together, we can work and act as a consolidator in this hugely fragmented industry."

He remains positive where the Indian healthcare market is concerned, citing a "huge demand-supply gap", an increasingly affluent middle class, as well as a growing incidence of lifestyle diseases such as heart disease or stroke.

"In a city like Delhi, there's a shortage of 6,000 beds. In Mumbai, it's as much as 10,000 beds," he pointed out.

India market

Mr Dhillon is also particularly bullish about its new hospital in Gurgaon, which was launched this year and will start contributing revenue from April next year. The multi-speciality hospital, which accounts for nearly a quarter of its portfolio valuation, is already churning out a higher revenue per operating bed of $330,000 vis-a-vis the average revenue per operating bed of $200,000 for the other beds across its portfolio.

In addition, RHT is eyeing five to six assets where Fortis acts as an operator, but doesn't own the asset. Last month, the trust announced it was in talks with regard to acquiring a clinical establishment in Mohali, Punjab, which is operated by Fortis.

Meanwhile, challenges facing the trust include the depreciation of the Indian Rupee, although RHT has tackled this by hedging its exposures.

"The policy is to continue to hedge 100 per cent of our distributable income, so on a six-month rolling basis, we hedge 100 per cent of our one year forward," he added.

Just last week, it announced that it had entered into forward currency hedging contracts for the year ending Dec 31, 2014.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dubai offices lie vacant due to their strata structure

Listen to this article

Published Mon, Dec 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[DUBAI] The Index tower on Dubai's answer to Wall Street has 23 floors of empty offices out of the 25 it opened in 2011. A few hundred feet away, buildings controlled by the Dubai International Financial Centre are almost full.

The difference is ownership. The office space in the Index on Sheikh Zayed Road was sold in pieces to nine different investors under a system known as strata title, according to developer Union Properties, meaning potential tenants face the prospect of having multiple landlords. The DIFC buildings have one owner, making it easier to lease large amounts of space to individual companies.

Offices that were divided into smaller parts to speed up sales and fund development have vacancy rates stuck at levels seen at the height of Dubai's real estate crisis even as homes, malls, hotels rebound. That's unlikely to change unless the government can find a way to persuade multiple owners to act as one on leases, according to Nick Maclean, broker CBRE Group's managing director for the Middle East.

site_title: Changi Airport's Project Jewel to cost $1.47b
content:
Changi Airport's Project Jewel to cost $1.47b

The development will boost airport's capacity and cement its position as a leading air hub

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

PROJECT Jewel, the mixed-use development aimed at adding some glitz to Changi Airport when it is launched by end-2018, will cost $1.47 billion including land costs.

Co-developers Changi Airport Group (CAG) and CapitaMallsAsia (CMA) said yesterday that they have struck a joint venture agreement via their respective wholly owned subsidiaries, Jewel Changi Airport Holding and CMA Singapore Investments (6), and will set up a private trust, a trustee-manager and a property manager as the JV entities.

CAG will hold the majority stake of 51 per cent, while CMA will hold the balance 49 per cent that it will bankroll through internal funds and external borrowings, CMA said in a release to the Singapore Exchange.

Project Jewel will be constructed on the existing 3.5-hectare carpark site in front of Terminal 1 and will include airport operations, retail and leisure offerings as well as hotel space. The site has a lease term of 60 years, expiring in 2073, with CAG as the lessor.

The project, which CAG describes as game-changing, is part of efforts to cement Changi's status as the region's preferred air hub as other airports strive to carve out a bigger slice of the pie.

CAG chief executive Lee Seow Hiang said: "In today's highly competitive landscape where airports around the world are actively competing for passengers' mindshare, we cannot stop innovating. Project Jewel will give us this additional edge."

Construction on Project Jewel will kick-start in the second half of next year, with completion slated for 2018 - not long after the upcoming Terminal 4 is set to open its doors in 2017.

A team of design consultants have been tasked with creating Changi Airport's latest landmark, which will be encased in a distinctive glass and steel dome. The consortium consists of Safdie Architects, which designed another local icon, the Marina Bay Sands integrated resort, Benoy, as well as local architect RSP, which was behind ION Orchard.

The multi-storey complex will span a total gross floor area of about 134,000 square metres, of which 17,000 sq m will go towards airport operations, 5,000 sq m towards hotel space, 90,000 sq m towards retail space as well as 22,000 sq m towards attractions such as a large indoor garden and 40-metre waterfall. However, the net lettable area of the retail space will total 53,500 sq m.

"The site presents an ideal opportunity for global and local retailers and F&B operators to create one-of-a-kind stores and dining concepts, to cater to a ready cosmopolitan catchment with more than 50 million passenger movements from 270 cities every year," said Lim Beng Chee, chief executive officer of CMA, which has interests in and manages 105 shopping malls across Asia. "This will provide an ideal platform both for American and European retailers to introduce and promote their offerings in Asia, as well as Asian retailers to do likewise with a global audience."

From an operational standpoint, Project Jewel will add a passenger handling capacity of three million to Changi's current tally of 66 million per year, in addition to allowing T1 to expand to accommodate greater space for areas such as taxi bays and baggage claim.

Aside from connecting passengers to the three existing terminals by foot, the development will also feature facilities dedicated to the fly-cruise and fly-coach passenger segments to make travel experiences smoother. Meanwhile, the basement carpark will nearly treble T1's existing parking facilities to 2,500 parking spots.

But Changi's transformation will not stop with T4 and the upcoming mixed-use development. Earlier this year, plans for the mega Terminal 5 were unveiled, which will bump up Changi's handling capacity to a total of 135 million passengers per year in the mid-2020s.

In the stock market yesterday, CMA shares closed at $1.905, up half a cent.

RHT enters into rupee forward contracts for '14

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

RELIGARE Health Trust (RHT) has entered into forward currency hedging contracts for its estimated incoming Indian rupee cashflow for the year ending Dec 31, 2014.

Religare Health Trust Trustee Manager has completed its currency hedging for the estimated incoming Indian rupee cashflow for the six months ending March 31, 2014 and Sept 30, 2014. The average rate of the forward contracts entered into are SGD1:INR 47.79 and SGD1:INR53.36, respectively.

"Over the past year, RHT's currency hedging strategy has allowed it to meet its projected distributions despite the depreciation of the INR as against the SGD. The trustee-manager intends to continue with its strategy to hedge its estimated INR cashflow on a one-year forward basis," said Religare yesterday.

RHT's current policy is to make distributions to unitholders on a semi-annual basis. Distributions, when made, are in Singapore dollars. Based on management's estimates of incoming Indian rupee cashflow, the trustee- manager enters into one-year forward contracts hedging such estimated amounts. As such, one year prior to the actual repatriation and conversion of INR to SGD, the trustee-manager would have locked in the exchange rate at which INR will be converted into SGD.

RHT's current portfolio comprises 11 RHT clinical establishments, four greenfield clinical establishments and two operating hospitals throughout India.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hisaka in $127m RTO deal with Regal Int'l

Move will transform the company into a Malaysian property development firm

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

HISAKA Holdings has signed a conditional agreement to buy Regal International in a $127.3 million reverse takeover deal that would transform the automation solutions provider into a Malaysian property development firm.

The move comes in anticipation of a "challenging" fiscal year in 2014 as the semi-conductor sector it operates in continues to be volatile with no imminent signs of recovery, it said.

The deal was entered into with four shareholders of Regal International, namely: Su Chung Jye, Wong Pak Kiong and Low Yew Shen, as well as Ikram Mahawangsa Sdn Bhd yesterday.

Mr Su is managing director of Regal Capital (a unit of Regal International) ; Mr Wong its director and head of sales and marketing; and Mr Low, a lawyer practising in Singapore and partner of Elitaire Law LLP. Ikram Mahawangsa is a Malaysian investment holding company 58 per cent owned by Mr Su and 29 per cent owned by Mr Wong.

Hisaka will pay Regal $20 million in cash, and issue 195 million new shares (after a two-into-one consolidation) at $0.55 apiece, as set out in its memorandum of understanding signed in July.

On completion, the vendors will own about 65 per cent of Hisaka's enlarged share capital.

Hisaka said: "The proposed acquisition represents a good opportunity for the group to expand and diversify its businesses and operations, which will allow it to achieve more consistent and sustainable financial growth."

Its balance sheet remains healthy and it stayed in the black in FY2012 and 2013 but net profits were "slim" at just $400,000 each fiscal year.

On a pro-forma basis, it sees its annual net profit being boosted to $575,000 after the acquisition, although earnings per share will dip slightly due to the diluted share count.

Regal's property development business will also improve Hisaka's business potential and prospects, it said.

"The future plans of the target group companies involve the expansion of its current property development business in Kuching, Sarawak, and expansion of its property development business to other areas outside Kuching, Sarawak."

Regal has multiple projects at various stages of development, including residential, commercial, shophouses, hotels and mixed developments.

Hisaka will appoint an independent professional valuer to conduct a valuation of Regal's business.

Besides shareholders and Singapore Exchange approvals, the agreement is also subject to Regal's obtaining a waiver to make a mandatory offer for Hisaka, as well as a condition that Regal achieves net earnings of at least $7 million for its fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2013.

Hisaka shares rose 7.7 per cent to end at 21 cents yesterday on the news.

site_title: Money thoughts for a lifetime
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Money thoughts for a lifetime

A year of articles on saving, spending, budgeting and life planning

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Dec 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

1

Money is important as a means to an end, and that end is arguably financial freedom. This happy state of affairs is defined by not having to work for a living, so one is freed to do whatever one deems important in life. This can be spending more time with the kids, travelling around the world, or taking time off to pursue a cause. With growing income inequality, ordinary people slogging in middle-class jobs might think they can never retire in their lives, and have to keep working till they are over 70. We beg to differ. For a start, those earning the median salary of $3,000 upon starting work stand a good chance of being able to attain financial freedom before they turn 60, or even 40 or 50.

This is because of two reasons: the mathematical effect of compounding, and the good financial habits one can build up over time. But you have to plan ahead, and above all, start young.

2

One question: Is one million dollars enough to retire on? Singapore is well-known for having one of the highest proportion of millionaire households in the world. Based on recorded spending patterns and a conservative rate of return of 4 per cent a year, along with inflation of 2 per cent a year, we calculated that $1 million would last a typical HDB family spending $3,600 a month today for 30 years. This means that a million dollars should theoretically be enough for a 50-something breadwinner to retire comfortably with. Of course, families spend more than $3,600 a month on both necessities like healthcare and more extravagant things like overseas holidays and overseas education. And the statistics show that a typical family living in a private flat or landed property could spend anywhere from $7,000 to $9,000 a month. In these scenarios, $1 million would not be enough to retire on.

site_title: UK latest to join trend of switching to plastic notes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

UK latest to join trend of switching to plastic notes

Britain will issue its first polymer note, a 'fiver', in 2016 , with the £10 version appearing a year later

Published

Fri, Dec 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Ottawa

IT took only 900 years, but paper money is fading away.

As a new technology, plastic bank notes, becomes more popular around the world, people will have to get used to money that is more slippery but less grimy and harder to fold into origami cranes but more likely to survive washing machines.

The decline of one of the world's greatest inventions gained momentum on Wednesday when Britain announced that the British pound, a reserve currency that has been printed on cotton-based paper for 300 years, will be made from plastic.

Britain is the latest nation to replace paper bills - starting with the £5 and £10 notes - with plastic ones.

Canada and Australia have already made the switch, as have about two dozen other countries.

Others, although not the United States, are expected to follow suit. The reason is simple enough: Plastic - or polymer, as it is called - holds up better than paper. It is also a lot harder to counterfeit.

Governments worry about such things, with good reason. But that is not what people who must now use polymer bills are concerned about. When Canada began introducing polymer notes in 2011, people grumbled about their slipperiness and their foldability. They thought the plastic bills would melt on hot radiators or car dashboards.

Some people convinced themselves that the notes were infused with a maple syrup scent, a notion that the Bank of Canada dismisses.

"One of the more improbable urban myths was that the intense heat in Canada caused the notes to melt," Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England and previously governor of the Bank of Canada, said at a news conference on Wednesday announcing the notes. "I can assure you that wasn't the case. Neither has the intense cold in Canada caused them to malfunction."

If a car interior got hot enough to melt a bill - that would be 284 degrees Fahrenheit, or 140 degrees Celsius - the car's interior plastics would begin to sag like a Salvador Dalí watch. Polymer bills can withstand temperatures as low as minus 103°F (minus 75°C), said Richard Wall, the director of currency at the Bank of Canada.

In an unscientific test using a household oven set to 280°F, a new C$5 note did not melt. But after eight minutes, it started to smell bad, shrink substantially and curl markedly. Its translucent security features also became opaque blobs.

Now that Canada has completed the transition, the complaints are fewer. But not everyone already using the new money is enthusiastic. In Ottawa, about 2 km south of the future new home of Canadian Bank Note Co, which prints the country's bills, is Di Rienzo Grocery and Deli, where about 300 sandwiches are snapped up each day by a steady stream of customers for C$5 apiece - cash only.

In the two years since the Bank of Canada first introduced polymer bills, Paolo Di Rienzo, the owner of the impossibly crowded and chaotic deli, has developed a long list of grievances. He says the bills stick to one another. Yet, he also says their slippery surface allows them to slip easily, unnoticed, out of pockets. The light, springy bills sometimes leap out of the cash register, according to Mr Di Rienzo. And, he says, polymer does not really fold.

"You have to really watch when they give you the money and when you give the money back," Mr Di Rienzo said. "The other ones were much better, the regular ones."

Overhearing Mr Di Rienzo while waiting for a sandwich, Domenico Nicolo, a taxi driver, pulled out a C$100 polymer note and began rubbing what he said was its excessively slippery surface. "A lot of people complain about them," Mr Nicolo said of his customers. He now checks much more carefully for bills that have stuck together.

The only good thing Mr Nicolo could say about polymer bills was that they survived accidental trips through washing machines.

One factor trumped everything when it came to Canada's decision to use polymer. "It was all about improving the security of bank notes," Bank of Canada's Mr Wall said. "We had a fairly substantial level of counterfeiting in 2004."

While Canada had already incorporated various holographic security devices in its paper bills, polymer enabled more complex protection.

The new Canadian bills have a transparent window that contains large, colour-shifting images of Parliament buildings and a portrait of Queen Elizabeth, Canada's formal head of state, or famous Canadian politicians. Small metallic details, including the note's denomination, also swirl around in the window. A circle of numbers appears in a second tiny window shaped like a maple leaf, the national symbol.

It was the success that Canada and other countries have had in warding off counterfeiters that prompted the Bank of England to consider plastic currency, according to Victoria Cleland, the head of the bank's notes division. "With bank notes, you want to understand how things have worked in true-life testing," Ms Cleland said.

The Bank of England made its decision on polymer notes after a long process in which the public was able to view and feel the bills during events at several malls and universities. The bank said 87 per cent of the people it talked to supported the move.

The first polymer note in Britain, a "fiver", will be released in 2016 and will feature Winston Churchill. A year later, Jane Austen will appear on a £10 note.

Mr Carney reassured the British public that the queen's visage would also appear on both notes. "Our polymer notes will combine the best of progress and tradition."

He also said it would make the British pound decidedly more presentable. "We have a bit of an issue in this country with the tattiness of notes over time. You think about the £5 note: Quite often you get one you want to get rid of as quickly as possible."

"Which is a good thing from an economic perspective, to some extent," he said with a laugh. NYT
