site_title: Tis the season for some reading
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tis the season for some reading

Want to put a book in someone's X'mas stocking? Here are seven recommendations from HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Mastermind: How To Think Like Sherlock Holmes

By Maria Konnikova, $32

BOOKS on how to think better are not always an easy read. But Maria Konnikova's Mastermind: How To Think Like Sherlock Holmes is something of an exception. Written in a breezy fashion, it splices excerpts of the detective's adventures with scientific studies on memory and reasoning. It offers good and sound advice on sharpening your powers of logic and observation.

But Konnikova doesn't stop at fiction and science. She also advocates practising a zen-like centredness, especially in times of crisis, because she believes it is most difficult to apply logic in those moments that matter the most. Learning to focus is not quite "elementary, my dear Watson" because our minds are prone to wander. But this book will have you convinced that training your brain is worth it. Holmes, for one, would certainly approve.

A Map of the World: The World According to Illustrators and Storytellers

By Antonis Antoniou (editor), $98

If you know a person who is curious about the world but doesn't like to read, you might want to get him A Map of the World: The World According to Illustrators and Storytellers. It's a compilation of more than 500 gorgeous, quirky maps by various artists, that don't quite illustrate parts of the world as much as they depict the way we live.

From a Kyushu Train All Stars map that shows what you can do on the Japanese island in cute, graphic terms, to an LA Film Map that renames Los Angeles roads according to appropriate film titles, some of these maps are abstract and profound, while others are downright funny. Cartography never seemed more fun.

How To Fail At Almost Everything and Still Win Big: Kind of the Story of My Life

By Scott Adams, $35

Remember Dilbert, the comic strip? For years, many white-collar office drones relied on Dilbert to find the funny side of the workplace with all its bureaucracies and mismanagement.

Now, its creator, Scott Adams, has written an autobiography of sorts which, like the cartoon, has a complete anti-career outlook. In short, he advises you to "invite failure in, embrace it, then pick its pocket".

Dismissing as rubbish a lot of typical career advice such as "follow your passion", Adams shows how goofy optimism, hard work and a logical way of calculating your odds are among the best ways to find success. Adams should know something about it, since Dilbert is his first real career success after a long series of failed get-rich schemes.

Lost Cat: A True Story of Love, Desperation, and GPS Technology

By Caroline Paul and Wendy McNaughton, $37.40

Know a cat lover? Get her Lost Cat, an illustrated novel that would charm her socks off - and perhaps those of other folk too. Author Caroline Paul tells a real-life story of how her cat Tibby went missing for five weeks - and then returned home nonchalantly, looking shinier and healthier than he ever did.

Unable to contain her curiosity, the author tried to find out what happened to Tibby. She distributed flyers, purchased a kitty-camera and tracked Tibby's movement using GPS. What she pieced together is nothing short of funny and surprising. Indeed, don't be fooled by the book's plain-looking cover. The story inside - together with Wendy McNaughton's illustration - is just purr-fect.

The Big New Yorker Book of Dogs

By The New Yorker magazine, $76

We would be remiss in our duties if we recommended a book for cat lovers but not for dog lovers. Well, the famous New Yorker magazine - a favourite of literatis - has published its own The Big New Yorker Book of Dogs. It's a wonderful compilation of short stories, essay and poems by very big names, including Roald Dahl, Arthur Miller, John Updike, Jonathan Lethem, Roddy Doyle and EB White, together with a foreword by Malcolm Gladwell and a new essay by Adam Gopnik.

For most New Yorker magazine readers, however, the icing on the cake has always been the cartoons by the magazine's staff which intersperse with the fine writing.

BOOKS FOR CHILDREN

The Day the Crayons Quit

By Drew Daywalt & Oliver Jeffers, $23

Need a gift for the young one? The Day the Crayons Quit has been charming kids since, well, the day in July when it was released.

Ranked as one of 2013's most popular kids' books by sites such as Amazon and Goodread, it tells the delightful story about a box of crayons that's gone rogue because the crayons feel either overworked or neglected: Blue is tired of colouring just water. Black wants to do more than just outline things. Yellow and Orange are fighting over sole rights to colour the sun.

If you're giggling, imagine the book's effect on kids.

Fortunately, the Milk

By Neil Gaiman and Chris Riddell, $19

Terrific title, eh? Well, the story's good too. Another kid's bestseller of 2013, Fortunately, The Milk tells the story of a pair of siblings who wakes up one morning to find no milk in the refrigerator. The father goes off to get milk and doesn't return for a very long time.

When he eventually does, he relates a fantastical tale of how he had already bought the milk but had to rescue it from monsters, aliens, pirates, wumpires (the cuter version of vampires) and other threats. Written by the faultless Neil Gaiman, it's a first-rate charmer.

site_title: EU bank bailout rules to take effect in 2016
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

EU bank bailout rules to take effect in 2016

They will ensure taxpayers don't pay for lenders' errors

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[STRASBOURG] European Union lawmakers have reached an agreement on rules for handling failing banks that lay the foundation for the bloc's push to make sure taxpayers don't foot the bill when lenders get into trouble.

"Big step tonight," EU commissioner Michel Barnier wrote on Twitter. "Taxpayers (are) no longer in front line" to pay for banks' mistakes, he added.

"Banks will have to put money aside for rainy days. We are learning lessons of crisis," he said after the agreement was reached by representatives of the European Parliament, the European Council - the EU's executive arm - and the 28 member states.

The aim is to make European banks stronger so that they "can lend to the real economy", he added.

"This is a fundamental step towards the completion of the Banking Union," Mr Barnier said in a separate statement.

The new system will take effect from 2016.

The "bail-in" will primarily require important hits to be taken by shareholders and bond holders of a financial institution in trouble.

Small depositors will be explicitly excluded from incurring any costs but depositors with more than 100,000 euros (S$172,600) could be affected, though lastly under a pre-defined hierarchy, the European parliament said.

For each member state, a fund will be established which will come to the aid of banks in order to help them recover or to wind them down.

These funds will be built up through bank contributions and by 2025 should reach the level of one per cent of the covered deposits of the banks in that country.

All banks will have to contribute but those contributions will be bigger for the banks that take the bigger risks, said Mr Barnier.

However the deal does not exclude the possibility of public money being used "in exceptional circumstances", the parliamentary statement said.

Welcoming the deal, Gunnar Hoekmark, who steered the legislation through the European parliament, said: "We now have a strong bail-in system which sends a clear message that bank shareholders and creditors will be the ones to bear the losses on rainy days, not taxpayers."

The deal must still be finalised on a technical level and will then need official approval by the EU member states and parliament.

The new directive will eventually dovetail with the EU's "Banking Union", which is being hammered out but will only apply to countries that use the common euro currency and others that choose to participate.

All countries now accept the principle that if banks get into difficulty, then it will not be the taxpayer but investors and creditors that bear the costs. But differences remain as to how to put that into practice.

EU ministerial talks in Brussels on Tuesday focused on a so-called Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) that would step in to close a bank at risk before it could do too much damage to the wider economy.

The SRM would have a pot of cash at its disposal - funded eventually by the banks themselves - to cover the cost involved so the taxpayer does not have to pick up the bill.

The SRM would follow an already agreed Single Supervisory Mechanism that the European Central Bank will run to oversee the top 130 or so eurozone banks directly, and thousands more indirectly via national authorities.

While all agree in principle, the political issues are fraught since the new system would effectively hand control of national banks to the EU.

Those talks will resume at ministerial level next week with hopes for agreement by the end of the month. - AFP

site_title: Painting by textures in photography
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Painting by textures in photography

Marcel Heijnen explores the idea of change and what is left behind, with a series on modern cityscapes, reports RACHEL LOI

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

MARCEL Heijnen wears many hats. In addition to being a graphic designer by trade, he helps run a cafe, is a singer-songwriter with a solo album to his name, and he is a photographer fresh off his exhibitions at both Hong Kong and Singapore's Affordable Art Fairs this year.

Right now, the latest thing keeping him busy is the release of his first book - a compilation of over 50 of his photographs, titled Residue.

The book was officially launched last night at his cafe, Artistry, together with his own exhibition of the same name.

Residue is a series of photographs taken against a weathered surface, with a clear acrylic panel between the surface and the camera adding a reflection of high-rise buildings in the shot.

Heijnen's photos are his way of exploring rapid urbanisation in Asian countries, namely Hong Kong, China, Indonesia and Singapore, by juxtaposing modern high-rise buildings against the textured walls or floors of older buildings worn and torn by nature.

Exploring urbanisation

"I don't know why I feel so strongly about urbanisation, but it's a very interesting theme because the world is moving towards that," says Heijnen, who was born in a small town in Holland but moved to Singapore two decades ago.

"Asia is my playground for this theme. I tried this in Europe, but there, you get a lot of old buildings. Juxtaposing that against old textures deflates the effect a little bit. Plus the Asian climate creates more interesting textures," he explains.

His prints are on sale at the cafe and his website, priced from $800 to $4,000 based on size and the number of pieces that were printed. Heijnen's book is also on sale for $65 at Kinokuniya's main store and Artistry, among other places.

On first look, Heijnen's works could easily be mistaken for a hipster's double-exposed piece of lomography, or even an abstract painting. Instead, they were shot with just his full-frame Nikon D600, and the aid of his acrylic panel.

No photo-editing is done beyond the basic cropping or dodge and burn, he promises.

"Everyone thinks my works are painted, or a product of Photoshop ... With some of my works, people go close to look at them at exhibitions, or look at them from the side. They think it's 3-dimensional," says Heijnen. "That's why I don't really see myself as a photographer so much, but more as a visual artist who uses photography."

His idea for this technique of combining textures and reflections developed four years ago, and according to him, it happened mostly by accident.

He was always obsessed with photographing textures and reflections, and had accumulated thousands of such photos in his personal collection, but he had never combined the two.

It was only during a trip to France in 2007, that he saw a shop window with scratches on its blue paint, and spontaneously took a shot of the building reflected in it.

Even then, it took another two years before he started making a series out of it.

"The principle elements of these photos are the same - buildings and texture. But what differentiates each photo is their unique formations, colours, and textures.

With depth

"I'm always looking for a texture that has a slight depth to it, so when the building is slightly out of focus, it feels like the two are merging. That's what I'm looking for - to merge the two, so it looks like it's painted, but it's actually painted by the texture," he explains.

Residue runs till Jan 19 at Artistry at 17 Jalan Pinang. Opening hours are from Tues to Sun, 10am to 7pm. Admission is free.

or call 6298 2420 for more information.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Yoma reaches beyond property in Myanmar

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

YOMA Strategic Holdings has long been known as a Myanmar property play, but a single industry is no longer enough for the company.

Yoma said yesterday that it had set up a second after-sales service centre for Mitsubishi vehicles in Myanmar. The announcement came shortly after the company also announced its involvement in building telecommunications towers and a new property deal.

Those announcements are part of Yoma's growing diversification, even though more than 90 per cent of total revenue still comes from property. The company now dabbles in auto servicing through its Mitsubishi partnership; telecommunications through a partnership with Digicel; and retail, through a joint venture to develop Parkson department stores in Myanmar.

"There is vast opportunity in Myanmar in a number of strategic sectors, and our key strength is that we are a partner of choice for many international companies looking to expand into Myanmar, as well as our ability to attract strong talent," Yoma chief executive Andrew Rickards told The Business Times.

Mitsubishi said a second after-sales service centre was set up in Mandalay on Dec 5, allowing Yoma's joint venture with Mitsubishi Motors Corp, Mitsubishi Corp and First Myanmar Investment Co to service almost 80 per cent of Mitsubishi vehicles in the country.

The business partners are now planning to sell new vehicles as well, and could even explore local production in the future.

"Timing will be driven by market conditions," Mr Rickards said.

The motivation behind Yoma's diversification is not difficult to understand. In a high-growth, frontier market like Myanmar, everything looks like an opportunity, while putting all the eggs in a single industry can seem risky.

The key is balance.

"The group remains focused on building a diversified conglomerate in Myanmar . . . We are building our non-real estate businesses, and are selectively expanding into other businesses in the country," Mr Rickards said. "We are confident that in the medium term, we expect to have a well-balanced portfolio of businesses."

Yoma shares closed flat at 73 cents yesterday.

site_title: In greater wonderment due to great whites
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

In greater wonderment due to great whites

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IN the past two weeks, I have had more whites than reds in the past six months - a most refreshing experience that included a Grand Cru Chablis, a Montrachet, a Corton Charlemagne and wonder of wonders, an Haut Brion Blanc!

Chablis Valmur Grand Cru 2009, Domaine Jean-Paul Droin

Very pale yellow with a lovely light lemony fragrance, almost perfume-like in its fineness. With the very first sip, you know it's a big wine, with great concentration of citrusy fruit and minerality. A very fresh taste, very rich with fruit. Attractive to drink now in what I would call "childhood", and deserves to be aged a minimum of 10 years, preferably more. This Domaine has a well-deserved reputation, the current generation being the 14th! True Chablis family, thus steeped in its tradition and folk-lore. Valmur has the reputation of being perhaps the weightiest of the Grands Crus. Weight and power, and always very rich in extract. A little less elegance than Les Clos and Blanchots, my two favourite Chablis Grands Crus. We should really see more of these Chablis; they are such a change from the usual Pulignys and Meursaults. This wine, for instance, was served with thinly sliced Australian abalone and what a magical combination, the minerally Chablis cleaning the palate after the smoky, slightly earthy taste of the abalone.

Montrachet 1993, Marquis de Laguiche by Maison Joseph Drouhin

Golden colour, nose of citrus and almonds; very good ripeness, medium length finish, now fully mature. Have seen better Laguiches though.

The Marquis de Laguiche Montrachet is my favourite Montrachet. Two reasons, the first being that it is a great wine, and the second, as important as the first or even more so, it is always most reasonably priced. And it ages beautifully. Drouhin farms and makes the wines from this vineyard in the Montrachet Appellation, the vineyard obviously belonging to the Marquis's family.

Corton Charlemagne 1992, Bonneau du Martray

A light golden colour. A lovely wine at just the right age. After the Montrachet, it appeared to be on the slim side. But very elegant and showed very good ripe fruit, very, very long. A great bottle.

Corton Charlemagne 1993, Faiveley

A Grand Cru, white burgundy by Faiveley that one hardly ever sees on the dinner table. One sip made me sit up. Corton Charlemagne Grand Cru 1993, Domaine Faiveley. I should have known.

Golden colour, very rich aroma of very ripe oranges and mixed nuts - the aroma of a very complex old white. On the palate, a big deep wine, very rich, intense and concentrated. Beautifully balanced, a gorgeous wine. Almost voluptuous.

A great white wine leaves me in greater wonderment than a great red. I think the extraordinary almost out-of-the-world flavours that a great mature white wine produces are more complex, more unusual, even sublime and rare, than those from a great mature red. Or mainly because they are much rarer than reds?

Chateau Haut Brion Blanc 1993

The Everest of the Graves Blanc brigade, and at the mature age of 20 years! Light golden colour, an aroma of orange peel and hay, atypical of Haut Brion Blanc. Very concentrated flavours, mixture of very ripe fruit and great acidity.

A very different flavour from the Chardonnay-based white burgundies. In Chardonnays, the aroma and taste remind of a blend of citrus fruit, mainly very lush ripe oranges, with a mixture of nuts, mainly almonds and peanuts, enveloped in a "bright" shining acidity.

In contrast, white Graves, especially the big guns, give me the impression of a "cooler" acidity, not rapier-sharp as in white burgundy. Must have something to do with the "free radicals"!

This Haut Brion Blanc was a splendid example of Grand Cru white Graves at its best. This is a rare wine - both in quantity and in its super-star price. Readers should take heart from the very fine white Graves now being produced by the likes of Domaine de Chevalier, Pape Clement, Smith Haut Lafitte, Malartic Lagraviere, and Latour Martillac.

These are well worth trying; they are inexpensive in comparison to Haut Brion Blanc and La Mission Haut Brion Blanc, the new name for Laville Haut-Brion.

Beaune Greves 1er cru Vigne l'Enfant Jesus 1997, Bouchard Pere et Fils

It is not often that Cote de Beaune reds appear on Singapore tables. Perhaps, they are not much seen on wine merchants' lists here. Or not in any demand? More likely the latter. So the opportunity to taste one, and a mature one at that, was most welcome.

A mature red showing the brownish tints of age. Soft ripe fruity nose, very pinot character - whiff of very ripe red berry fruit. A wine with very ripe fruit, very well balanced and very pleasant to drink but lacks complexity. Apart from that, it was actually very good!

Musigny Grand Cru 1994, Comtes de Vogue

Nineteen years old and showing this in its dark brown-red colour. A very fine "pinot" aroma, fresh and delicate, aroma of red berries which was reflected on the palate but I thought there was insufficient ripeness although very good acidity salvaged the otherwise poor impact. An interesting example of the 1994 vintage in Burgundy, where it rained during harvest and diluted the acidity but not the ripeness. Perhaps this wine might have shown better when it was younger, say at 10 years' age.

Richebourg 1999, Gros Frere et Soeur

The big guns now.

Very dense, dark red colour, virtually black-red. Hardly any brown tints even at the edges. A beautiful, very fine aroma, a blend of blackcurrant sweetness combined with lovely acidity and good balance. The taste was a mixture of very ripe fruit, mainly very fresh oranges blended with a mixture of nuts, mainly cashews and almonds. Very complex indeed, but so good! At top maturity and a fabulous drink.

Gros Frere et Soeur is the third member of the Jean Gros family who trace their origin in Burgundy to Alphonse Gros, who settled in Vosne-Romanee in 1830 after marrying Madame Latour. From this family came Domaine Jean Gros, founded by his great-great-grandson Jean Gros in 1963. Hence, Domaine Jean Gros. Gros Frere et Soeur was formed by two of the fourth generation of the Gros family! And it is one of Jean Gros's children, Bernard, who is the winemaker for Gros Frere et Soeur. Tracing the history of the wine-making families in Burgundy is tougher than doing a jigsaw puzzle!

A remarkable family though, now into its fifth generation!

A disclaimer needed: I am involved in the distribution of Domaine Bonneau du Martray's wines

Correction:

Last week, I wrote: "d'Alba and thus has a commanding view of the valley below and the mountain range in the distance. A beautiful site. Brunello Riserva Montfortino, Giacomo Conterno, is unquestionably Piedmont's finest and greatest Brunello, desperately sought after world-wide. (It reminds me of Roumier's Musigny!) His other wines, the regular Brunello, Brunello Cascina Francia". For Brunello, please read Barolo. My apologies for this error and the confusion it might have caused.

Linc Energy launches IPO; secures Genting Bhd unit as strategic investor

Company plans to raise about $47.9m in net proceeds

Published

Wed, Dec 11, 2013 · 10:00 PM

UPSTREAM oil and gas firm Linc Energy, which is moving its listing from the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) to Singapore Exchange, plans to raise about $47.9 million in net proceeds through a mainboard initial public offering (IPO) of 47.85 million shares, with an over-allotment option of four million shares.

Some 47.35 million shares will be placed out to international investors, including institutional investors, while 500,000 shares will be offered to the public, at $1.20 apiece. These will make up about 8.4 per cent of the post-IPO total issued share capital of 571.15 million shares. The market cap on listing will be some $685 million.

The group yesterday also said that it had secured Genting Strategic Investments (Singapore) as a strategic investor.

The wholly owned subsidiary of Genting Berhad - the investment holding and management company of Genting Group which also owns palm plantations in Malaysia - plans to subscribe for 47.85 million of the offer shares. Part of these will come from the over-allotment option.

Genting also has an option to subscribe for up to 10.75 million shares at the offer price any time from the listing date till six months after.

Linc Energy's oil and gas assets, which generate the bulk of its profits, are in the Gulf Coast region, Wyoming and Alaska in the United States.

The first two are already producing, while the last is still in exploration stage.

It has 2P (proven plus probable) oil reserves of 168 million barrels.

The group also holds licences to more than 65,000 contiguous square kilometres in the Arckaringa Basin in South Australia that has been found to be rich in shale reserves.

The firm intends to spend about US$10 million in capital expenditure next year to develop the shale block, its managing director Peter Bond told reporters yesterday.

For a start, it will drill six vertical wells, and will then look for a partner to bring the project forward.

A partnership in the form of a joint venture or other forms of investment can "unlock the value" of the asset, said Mr Bond.

The firm also owns underground coal gasification technology, which involves burning coal while it is still in the seam and capturing the gas for use in power generation or feedstock in liquid fuels, fertilisers or chemical products.

Of the $47.9 million to be raised (assuming no over-allotment), about $18.8 million will be used for its conventional oil and gas business.

Some $23.5 million will go towards its clean-energy business, in particular to develop the UCG project in Poland and South Africa, and for other project development activities in Europe, Russia, North America and Asia.

The rest will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes.

Credit Suisse (Singapore), DBS Bank and JP Morgan (SEA) are the joint issue managers, bookrunners and lead managers.

Linc Energy's IPO closes at noon next Monday. Trading is expected to start at 2pm on Wednesday.

The group, which first listed on the ASX in 2006, recorded revenue of A$124.4 million (S$141 million) for the 2013 financial year, and a net loss to shareholders of A$26.7 million.

site_title: Searching for 'oh my god' art
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Searching for 'oh my god' art

From around the world, five collectors of South-east Asian art share their wisdom on how to build an art collection. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

HOWARD TAM

47, USA

Technical director of a medical technology firm

HOWARD Tam applies a simple rule of thumb when deciding whether to buy art: "I categorise art into three baskets - oh, oh my and oh my god. The oh my god is the top tier.

"I buy only works that are oh my god. Works that are oh my may slip down the list to become oh; works that are just oh may slip off the list altogether. The oh my god are the ones you should collect."

So far, that strategy has worked like a charm. The pieces belonging to his collection currently on display at Artspace@Helutrans include some extraordinary works such as Sopheap Pich's Buddha, one of only three in the world.

The famous Cambodian rattan sculpture comes apart in its bottom half, as a symbol of how goodness and humanity unravelled under the Khmer Rouge rule, which the artist witnessed as a child.

Mr Tam says: "There are two things I think about. First, whether the work has a deeper political, social and religious meaning. Second, how does that work fit into the artist's entire body of work? Does it represent a progression? Or is he just producing more of the same?"

"Oh my god" artworks seldom come cheap, and Mr Tam has seen his budget for each work rise from US$20,000 in 2005 to around US$100,000 these days. He has amassed some 250 pieces of mostly South-east Asian artists that include the Who's Who of the art world, such as Filipino Ronald Ventura, Indonesia's Handiwirman Saputra and Malaysia's Yee I-Lann.

Mr Tam is clear about one thing, though - he doesn't buy art to speculate. Even though several of the works have seen their value rise, he's never sold a piece.

One day, the American hopes to loan or donate them to museums in the United States which he feels need greater exposure to South-east Asian art.

He says: "To collect art for investment's sake would be rather foolish. You'll get burned because you never know when the tide will turn. Artists who may be hot right now may collapse in two years. And art is not liquid - not like stocks or real estate."

"There are wiser ways to spend your money," he notes. "Collecting art requires genuine passion."

Final word of advice:

"I have very few Singaporean artists in my collection. Historically, I've been very cynical about Singaporean artists. I generally found the works derivative ... And even among many Singapore collectors, I noticed there wasn't strong interest in local art.

"But in the past 10 years, I've seen a lot of progress. The young generation of Singapore artists are producing some really good works, so I recommend that collectors look at Singapore art now.

"My picks include Robert Zhao, Donna Ong, Joel Yuen and Jane Lee."

Part of Tam's art collection is currently on show at Artspace@Helutrans, 39 Keppel Road, #02-03, Tanjong Pagar Distripark, from now till Dec 15. Opening hours: 11am to 7pm daily. Admission is free. Call 6329-6847 for details.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Alitalia secures 300m euros in new capital, reassures unions

Published

Wed, Dec 11, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[MILAN] Alitalia has finally secured the 300 million euros (S$517 million) it needs to keep flying over Christmas, a source said on Tuesday, concluding a drawn- out capital raising that showed how much work the airline has to convince investors it can survive.

The cash call was part of a bigger government-engineered rescue to keep Alitalia going while it searches for a new partner willing to invest in revamping its fleet and making it profitable in the longer term.

The scale of that task was illustrated by the airline's difficulty in persuading shareholders to sign up for fresh investment - many aired doubts over its proposed business plan or wanted to see a tougher restructuring of the airline's debt.

The source said Italy's state-owned postal service, which had been lined up to commit up to 75 million euros for any unsubscribed shares, had to participate in the cash call in the end, although to what extent was not yet known.

"Including subscriptions by existing shareholders, new investors and the investment by the postal service, the 300 million euro target has been reached," the source said.

An Alitalia spokeswoman said the company would comment on the outcome of the capital increase in due course.

Alitalia's management presented details of its revised industrial plan to trade unions on Tuesday, reassuring them that feared layoffs of thousands of people would not be part of its moves to return the airline to profitability.

Unions have vowed to gear up for a battle should any layoffs be announced. Any tough restructuring of the airline to suit a foreign investor would also weigh on the already fragile coalition government of Enrico Letta. A union representative who took part in the meeting said Alitalia was targeting total cost savings of 295 million euros, with some 128 million euros to be obtained through salary cuts or by freezing pay increases.

"This whole plan focuses only on cuts, but does not present an industrial perspective for the company nor is there talk of a possible partner," said Guido Barcucci, a spokesman for the CGIL union. "In this form, this is a non-starter."

He said Alitalia proposed to postpone an earlier plan to increase its presence on more lucrative intercontinental routes. Boosting the number of long-haul flights has so far been seen as imperative to turn Alitalia's fortunes around.

Management and unions will meet again, although no date has been set yet.

The capital raising, later extended to new investors including Italian businessman Antonio Percassi, is likely to allow Alitalia to keep flying throughout the key Christmas holiday season.

But with daily losses of around 700,000 euros and net debt of more than 800 million euros, the company could risk having to ground its fleet again within six months, analysts said, unless a strong partner is found.

"With this fresh capital, Alitalia's problems have been swept under the carpet for a few months, but by summer next year they will reappear," a Milan-based analyst said. "Alitalia needs much more than 300 million euros to revamp its fleet so it can finally start making revenues. Three to four billion euros is more like it."

Top shareholder Air France-KLM, which has a 25 per cent stake and had been seen as most likely to come to Alitalia's rescue, was one of several investors to snub the rights offer. The Franco-Dutch group said Alitalia's pledge to make severe cost cuts was not enough to save it without its creditors having to write off some of its debt.

Over the years, other major airlines, including Lufthansa and British Airways, have flirted with partnering the carrier, which offers access to Europe's fourth-largest travel market and flies 25 million passengers a year - but decided it was too much of a gamble.

On Tuesday, daily la Repubblica said Alitalia and Etihad Airways were in advanced talks on a possible investment by the Abu Dhabi-based airline. Etihad declined to comment. - Reuters

Dorms urged to provide activities for foreign workers this weekend

Cooling-off steps to keep workers away from Little India

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has encouraged the major dormitory operators here to provide more recreational activities for their foreign-worker residents this weekend, while "cooling-off measures" will be introduced in the wake of last Sunday's riot in Little India.

The measures aim to deter foreign workers from going to Little India on Sunday and to give "the different communities affected by the riot time and space to recover" from the incident, the police, Land Transport Authority (LTA) and MOM said in a joint statement yesterday.

MOM has been in close touch with dormitory operators, such as Vobis, Westlite and Keppel Housing, as well as employers associations like the Singapore Contractors' Association, the Association of Singapore Marine Industries and the Association of Process Industry. It has also spoken to some employers on the matter.

Noting that some dorms were already organising activities for their residents, MOM said it "has urged vigilance and calm, and to provide workers with reassurance that police investigations are under way and will be conducted fairly".

Channel News Asia reported that the Dormitory Association of Singapore had issued an advisory yesterday, recommending that its members organise more activities for workers to remain indoors and use the dormitory facilities. They were also told to tell their resident workers to avoid Little India unless for work or business purposes.

The dormitory association also asked its members to beef up their security by, for instance, increasing operational staff, as well as establishing or activating emergency recall systems.

To keep foreign workers away from Little India on Sunday, LTA and Public Transport Council (PTC) will temporarily suspend the 25 Little India bus services run by private bus operators. The two bus associations, Singapore School Transport Association and Singapore School and Private Hire Bus Owners' Association, have been informed of the suspension.

In addition, the police have suspended the sale and consumption of alcohol at Little India and its surrounding vicinity, from 6am this Saturday to 6am next Monday. The suspension of alcohol sales will affect about 374 establishments in Little India and its vicinity, including areas such as Mackenzie Road, Race Course Road, Farrer Park and Petain Road. The affected establishments include liquor shops, restaurants, hotels, pubs, coffee shops and convenience shops.

The police will also deploy officers to conduct enforcement checks on outlets in the affected areas. Violators would be liable to a fine not exceeding $5,000 on conviction and could run the risk of losing their liquor licences.

Little India will be declared a "proclaimed area" under the Public Order (Preservation) Act, where police officers can take action against anyone who consumes alcohol in the area, including seizing the alcohol. The police may also arrest anyone who is drunk and behaving in a disorderly manner under the Miscellaneous Offences (Public Order and Nuisance) Act.

"In deciding the next steps after this weekend, the police will have to carefully weigh these considerations and balance the interests - some of which are competing - of the various stakeholders. Eventually, the police are likely to recalibrate the alcohol ban in a graduated and measured way. Even after we have lifted the alcohol ban, there will in most likelihood continue to be certain restrictions on the sale of alcohol, and certain areas where alcohol consumption will not be allowed," said the statement.

Both the Transient Workers Count 2 and the Migrant Workers Centre will be holding events to celebrate International Migrants Day this Sunday, which they hope will help the workers stay out of trouble.

Meanwhile, four more Indian nationals, aged between 24 and 45 years, were charged in court yesterday for rioting under Section 147, taking the total number brought to the docks so far to 31.

Three of the four men were charged for throwing concrete pieces at police officers. The fourth was charged for rioting with five others and damaging the bus involved in the fatal accident by throwing a dustbin at its front window, smashing the windscreen with a wooden stick and throwing pieces of hardened concrete, bottles and a metal drain cover at the windscreen and windows of the bus. He is accused of overturning and setting alight a police car.

The four have been remanded for further investigations and will return to court on Dec 19.

site_title: Buying art on a budget
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Buying art on a budget

From around the world, five collectors of South-east Asian art share their wisdom on how to build an art collection. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

HADY ANG

61, Singapore

Deputy director of a transport-related company

IF you weren't born with a silver spoon in your mouth and you wish to collect art, you may want to follow the footsteps of the Vogels or Hady Ang.

Mr Ang, 61, began collecting Chinese antiques in 1979 on his modest civil servant's salary. But, by the 1990s, the prices of Chinese antiques had risen so much that he could not afford them.

So he turned his attention to South-east Asian art instead and became one of the most avid local collectors of the region's art - amassing under 100 works by the likes of Geraldine Javier, Agus Suwage and FX Harsono.

His biggest buy is a stunning piece titled Resurrection by Ronald Ventura, which features a Christ-like figure with Asian features painted on a door, bought for an undisclosed sum. He says: "I have a limited budget, so I have to be very, very selective. And I don't pay for everything at one go - I pay by credit or instalments, and often incur interest charges."

But the interest is worth it, he thinks, because some of his works have seen their value rise substantially over the years - especially the ones he bought before South-east Asian art prices took off in the late 2000s.

Mr Ang, who rose through to the ranks to become a deputy director in his company, certainly has advice for novice collectors buying on a budget. He says: "If you're buying for investment, don't buy $2,000 to $4,000 works, or these so-called affordable art. You'll find that, in most cases, these works will get you nothing in return.

"Instead, focus on blue-chip artworks by the top 20 artists in the region. If you need to, save up for one expensive work above $10,000 instead of buying three or four cheap works. If you need to, share the costs and risks with a friend."

Mr Ang says he learnt about the importance of buying only the best in the early years when he was buying only Chinese fineware: "If you buy an average quality piece and later try to sell it, the good auction houses will not take it and you're not likely to get the kind of returns you hope for."

Mindful of the huge financial risks of collecting art, Mr Ang focuses on other investments as well, such as property, to finance his passion for art.

In the early years, when there was little international interest in the Asian art scene, he made it a point to befriend the artists whose works he collects. Today, he counts many famous Indonesian artists like Suwage and Jumaldi Alfi as his friends.

He plans to hold an exhibition of his collection next year.

Final word of advice:

"Look for art with a strong historical context, that give you an insight into the issues affecting the region. That kind of art is more relevant and enduring."

Vietnam mall operator wants to expand to more cities

Vingroup will use part of US$200m bond sale proceeds to build a mall in Ha Long Bay next year

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[HANOI] Vingroup JSC, Vietnam's largest property developer and mall operator, will look beyond the country's two biggest cities to build shopping centres and woo the growing number of middle-class consumers.

The company, based in Hanoi, will use part of the US$200 million it raised from the sale of bonds last month to fund a seven-story mall in the tourist city of Ha Long Bay in 2014, chief executive officer Le Thi Thu Thuy said in an interview. It will also open malls in cities including Hai Phong, Can Tho, Da Nang and Binh Duong over the next few years, she said.

Vingroup, founded by billionaire chairman Pham Nhat Vuong, will compete with Korea's Lotte Group to add malls in cities other than Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, luring consumers in a country where more than half the population of 90 million people is below the age of 30. The companies are expanding their retail reach as per capita income in the nation is expected to double next year from its 2009 level.

"Vietnam's consumer market has so much potential," Ms Thuy said yesterday in Hanoi. "It always makes sense to be the first big mall in any big city."

Options for consumers in Vietnam's urban cities outside of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City are limited, said Ralf Matthaes, a Ho Chi Minh City-based regional managing director at market research firm TNS.

Shares of Vingroup dropped 0.7 per cent in Ho Chi Minh City at open yesterday. The stock has climbed 18 per cent this year, compared with the 22 per cent gain in the VN Index.

Vietnam's middle class is growing. The International Monetary Fund estimates per capita income in Vietnam to almost double to US$2,174 next year from US$1,182 in 2009.

Lotte Group opened its sixth shopping centre this month in Phan Thiet. The mall, spread over 7,000 square meters, is Lotte's largest retail centre in the country's central region and the first by a foreign company in Binh Thuan province, according to website VietnamPlus, citing the local operator, Lotte Mart Vietnam.

Vingroup, which also develops residential properties and operates resorts, will consider malls in cities with population of more than one million. It plans to build shopping centres in Can Tho and Danang by 2016, Ms Thuy said. Vincom Retail, the division that operates the malls, will open its sixth shopping centre in two weeks in Hanoi. The company sold a mall in Ho Chi Minh City earlier this year.

Shopping centres can bring in traffic by offering entertainment and dining choices, TNS's Matthaes said.

Vingroup has taken note of Vietnamese consumers' penchant to go to malls for food and drinks, says Ms Thuy. Its malls have a higher food and beverage mix than is typical in Southeast Asia and is designed to be an entertainment complex, she said.

"In Vietnam, the dining culture is big and food and beverage brings in customers," she said. "People go to malls to eat and then shop."

The company opened its Vincom Mega Mall Royal City in Hanoi in July. Vingroup says the shopping centre is Asia's largest underground mall with more than 180,000 square metres of restaurants, shops, a skating rink and a waterpark.

Revenue from Vingroup's malls will reach about US$75 million this year, up from about US$58 million last year, she said. The company plans to begin construction of a megamall in Ho Chi Minh City in the second half of next year, she added.

Real estate leasing accounted for about 16 per cent of Vingroup's revenue last year, according to its financial statement.

Vingroup's strategy to increase recurring revenue from its malls and hospitality services is sound, said Dinh Thi Mai Anh, a Hanoi-based analyst at Saigon Securities, which has a "hold" rating on the company.

"It would be good for the group to maintain its stable cash flow when the overall residential sales segment does not show strong performance," she said. "This also eases pressure of debt payments."

Still, Vingroup's mall expansion comes as consumer demand cools. Retail sales rose almost 13 per cent in the eleven months through November, the slowest pace since at least 2005, according to government data. Vietnam's economic growth of 5.25 per cent last year was the weakest since 1999. The government forecasts the economy will expand 5.4 per cent this year.

With the economic slowdown, price-sensitive consumers have turned to traditional mom-and-pop stores and neighbourhood open- air markets for everyday needs, Mr Matthaes said. Sales at shopping malls and other modern outlets increased 11 per cent this year, slower than the 19 per cent pace in 2012, he said.

Developers should be considering building more affordable centres that cater to middle class consumers, he said.

"Everyone's building these five-star shopping malls no one can afford. They should be building two- or three- star malls which would make it affordable for tenants and consumers."

Vingroup raised money from an overseas bond sale last month as it prepares to boost its mall operations, Ms Thuy said. The company announced in May that Warburg Pincus LLC, the private- equity owner of Neiman Marcus Group, is leading a consortium to invest as much as US$325 million. - Bloomberg

Invest with care in emerging markets

Listen to this article

Published Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

AFTER more than a decade as a global market darling, emerging market equities and bonds have suffered a humbling comeuppance. Over the past three years, returns have turned negative; the broader MSCI Emerging Markets Index has been relatively resilient with an annualised loss of 3 per cent, compared with a loss of more than 9 per cent per annum for Latin America.

Not surprisingly, some are raising the question of whether the structural growth story that had long underpinned expectations for emerging assets is finally over. For now, among investment strategists, the consensus view remains in favour of developed markets such as the US and Europe, and to give emerging markets a miss. There are a few reasons for this view, foremost of which is that a tapering of quantitative easing (QE) measures - widely expected by the first quarter of 2014 - would trigger fund outflows and hurt emerging markets. Markets saw a dry run of this scenario earlier this year.

There are a number of fundamental reasons for negativity in the near term. One is slower growth in China, whose economy is rebalancing towards a more consumption-driven engine. This has had knock-on effects on raw material suppliers such as Indonesia, for example.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Battle for Australian office trust heats up

Dexus, CPPIB's hike of joint offer may spark higher bids

Published

Wed, Dec 11, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] A bidding war for Australia's Commonwealth Property Office Fund escalated after Dexus Property Group and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board hiked their joint offer - a move expected to prompt a higher bid from a rival suitor.

The latest cash and stock offer values CPA, as the fund is known, at A$3 billion (S$3.42 billion) and represents a 2.6 per cent premium over a bid from rival property investor GPT Group, Dexus said.

The value of both bids fluctuate according to the share price moves of Dexus and GPT.

Both Dexus and GPT are large diversified property firms keen to lift their exposure to Australian office real estate which delivers high yields but analysts say the stakes are higher for GPT which has failed to clinch two other deals.

"It must be remembered that GPT has had two recent unsuccessful attempts to expand its portfolio, and another failure would be a real hit to management's credibility," said Shannon Rivkin, a director at Rivkin.

Dexus will own 14.9 per cent of CPA in January after exercising a derivatives contract.

GPT said it has no stake in CPA at the moment but has an agreement to own 8 per cent if it declares its offer unconditional.

GPT is 11.6 per cent owned by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC.

A GPT spokesman said the company had noted the proposal but declined further comment.

CPA owns 26 office buildings in major business districts across Australia.

For foreign investors such as GIC and CPPIB, Australian office property offers a clearly regulated market with attractive yields - currently around 7.33 per cent for central business district buildings, according to Jones Lang LaSalle.

That compares to yields of 4.6 per cent for New York and 4.0 per cent for London, it said.

Foreign investment in Australian property, including hotels, office space and retail malls, almost doubled year on year to A$39.4 billion last year, Jones Lang LaSalle said.

Dexus and the Canadian fund are now offering a cash payment of A$0.7745 and 0.4516 Dexus security per unit, valuing each CPA unit at A$1.27 based on Dexus' closing price on Tuesday.

By comparison, GPT is offering A$0.75325 in cash and 0.141 GPT security for each CPA unit.

"It (the Dexus offer) has a higher cash component which offers certainty given the fluctuation of share prices of Dexus and GPT," said John Kim, a Reit analyst at CLSA.

Dexus has also removed its minimum acceptance condition, giving it another advantage over GPT.

Commonwealth Managed Investments Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of Commonwealth Bank of Australia, manages CPA on behalf of unit holders. It said it would consider the revised bid from Dexus and CPPIB. - Reuters

site_title: Quieter year seen ahead after 'tale of two halves'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Quieter year seen ahead after 'tale of two halves'

Compared with previous cooling measures, TDSR had the biggest impact on the market in 2013

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Coming on the heels of a dramatic year peppered with policies aimed at cooling the property market and a number of firsts in public housing, 2014 appears poised to be a more subdued year by comparison.

Consultants say it is unlikely that the government will roll out any new policies next year, even though they do not rule out some tweaking of existing measures.

"Policy changes, if any, may most likely be of the 'unwinding' kind - that is, rolling back earlier policies," said Chua Yang Liang, head of research, South-east Asia, at Jones Lang LaSalle. "The timing will depend very much on the pace of economic growth and the response from the property market during the period. We reckon a healthy long-term growth rate of 1-2 per cent a quarter on the Property Price Index is what the state is comfortable with."

Chia Siew Chuin, Colliers International's director of research and advisory, does not expect new measures to be introduced, given that the ramifications of existing measures are still being felt in the various segments.

The most significant event this year was the implementation of the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework, whose impact cut across the private residential, as well as the strata-titled retail, office and industrial sectors, she noted.

The TDSR, which came into effect on June 29, required that lenders consider a borrower's total debt obligations (including other mortgages and loans for cars) before granting a new home loan. The total debt obligations ceiling was set at 60 per cent of a buyer's gross monthly income.

This followed the seventh round of cooling measures, announced in January, which included lower loan-to-value limits, higher cash downpayments, size curbs on EC (executive condominium) developments, and anti-speculation moves targeted at the industrial sector. Notably, a seller's stamp duty was imposed on the industrial sector for the first time.

Given the two rounds of measures, Ms Chia described 2013 as a "a tale of two halves". The implementation of the TDSR, she said, marked a turning point for the healthy level of sales for strata-titled, non-residential properties which was seen in the first half of the year.

"To date, TDSR appears to have had the most far-reaching impact on property compared with the previous property-specific measures. Overall, residential prices will end about 2 per cent higher from a year ago and flat over the last quarter. For the most part, developers have been able to hold onto current prices for luxury projects but may be pressured to adjust prices to a competitive level with more projects receiving their Temporary Occupation Permits (TOP) next year," said Joseph Tan, executive director, residential, at CBRE.

On the public housing front, the mortgage servicing ratio (MSR) of 30 per cent curbed demand as buyers were no longer able to afford to upgrade to larger flats with smaller loans.

This has helped stabilise the HDB resale market, noted Eugene Lim, key executive officer of ERA Realty. In addition, cash over valuation (COV) has continued to fall, with more flats changing hands with no COV or below valuation, he said.

"HDB resale transactions are likely to remain low for now, but we are hopeful of volumes increasing after the festive period as more buyers come back into the resale market, attracted by the prospects of being able to pick up a property at or below valuation, particularly in the non-mature estates," said Mr Lim.

Mohamed Ismail, chief executive officer at Propnex Realty, has a more conservative outlook for the HDB resale market.

With demand sapped by the release of new Build-To-Order (BTO) flats - 77,000 BTO flats were launched in the past three years to quell the voracious demand for homes - the resale market is effectively serving only the upgraders and permanent residents who have attained three- year status now, he noted.

This, combined with the various rounds of property measures aimed at keeping price growth sustainable, will create a "balancing effect" in the resale market, gradually softening price growth to a more sustainable level.

This year, he expects HDB flat prices to dip one per cent. By end-2014, flat prices are expected to fall by up to 5 per cent as a result of the falling prices of all HDB flats when the 77,000 new flats come on stream, he added.

Against this backdrop of multi-pronged approaches to stabilise the market, a number of significant announcements that are expected to have a major long-term positive impact were also unveiled this year.

These included the freeing up of some 800 hectares of land with the moving of Paya Lebar airbase to Changi, and the unveiling of plans for new housing areas, such as Bidadari, Tampines North, and Punggol Matilda.

The government has also tried to meet the various housing needs of different groups after satisfying the needs of first-time married couples. Its initiatives include the unprecedented move of allowing eligible singles to buy new two-room HDB flats in non-mature estates, and the pilot launch of Three-Generation (3Gen) flats catering to multi-generation families, which was warmly received.

November marked the rolling out of a record 8,952 flats, the largest joint BTO and sale of balance flats exercise.

With such laudable moves in the public-housing space, Colliers' Ms Chia said she looks forward to equally "incisive and targeted initiatives" in the industrial and commercial sectors.

What is needed is a more intentional and detailed approach to addressing the different types of business requirements in the industrial and commercial property sectors. This means that the eventual building must meet end-users' needs without ambiguity, said Ms Chia.

"Should there be a mismatch between the type of real estate formats and the real needs of users, planning efforts will be futile and scarce resources will be wasted," she said.

Looking ahead into 2014, the retirement housing sector will be worth keeping an eye on, given Singapore's demographic trends and ageing population, said Lee Lay Keng, head of Singapore research at DTZ.

"It'll be interesting to see what the take-up will be for the retirement village at Jalan Jurong Kechil that is currently being planned by World Class Land. We could see more of such developments going forward if the project attracts strong buyer interest," she said.

Elsewhere, Knight Frank Singapore's research head, Alice Tan, said that assuming global economic growth improves, she expects the office sector to make a comeback in 2014 with greater interest from investors and space users.

"The positive prospects of improving occupancy and rentals with more businesses choosing to set up their operations in Singapore, combined with an improving global market outlook, would provide a boost to the office sector," she said.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Vallianz shareholders back fund-raising, diversification plans

Published

Wed, Dec 11, 2013 · 10:00 PM

VALLIANZ Holdings, an integrated offshore marine solutions services provider in the oil and gas industry, has received shareholder approval for its plans to boost its capital base and diversify its business.

The go-ahead came at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Monday.

Under an option agreement, Vallianz will grant 500 million non-transferrable share options at an exercise price of 5.5 cents per option to mainboard-listed offshore oil and gas company Swiber Holdings. This could help it raise US$22 million, assuming all options are exercised.

Shareholders also gave the green light for an issuance of capital securities to Saudi Arabia-based offshore oil and gas company Rawabi. Under this agreement, Rawabi will subscribe to US$35.2 million of the capital securities, which can be converted to 800 million shares in Vallianz.

Darren Yeo, CEO of Vallianz, said the strengthening of its capital base through the funding exercise is "in line with our current plan to deepen our capital structure, including exploring Islamic financing through a sukuk programme".

In total, Catalist-listed Vallianz could raise up to US$57.2 million in proceeds, which are intended for future fleet expansion and general working capital.

"We will look for opportunities to tap Swiber's strong business network by providing long-term charters to third parties while our partnership with Rawabi will enable us to strengthen our position in the Middle East," Mr Yeo added.

The company also received approval at the EGM to diversify its business into sourcing and supplying of vessels and equipment, and additional shipping-related services to the offshore oil and gas industry.

Mr Yeo said any new business that Vallianz enters into will be "synergistic" with the current businesses of marine asset ownership, leasing and fleet corporate management.

Shares in Vallianz closed 1.6 per cent down yesterday at 12.4 cents.

site_title: Libya PM expects ports to reopen on Sunday
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Libya PM expects ports to reopen on Sunday

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[TRIPOLI] Libya's government expects eastern tribes to reopen three oil ports this weekend as pledged but refuses to deal with an autonomy movement demanding a share of oil exports, Prime Minister Ali Zeidan said on Wednesday.

On Tuesday, tribal leaders blocking three eastern ports that had shipped around 600,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil said they would end the stoppage on Sunday but some also demanded the government share oil exports.

Such seizures have slashed Libya's oil exports to 110,000 bpd, from more than one million bpd in July, and added to chaos in the North African country two years after the fall of Muammar Gaddafi.

The loss of oil has dried up the main source of budget revenues and dollars for food imports, forcing the government to seek loans or use its foreign currency reserves.

"We trust in the tribal leaders and important individuals who held talks with us in the past 10 days and reached this agreement," Mr Zeidan told a news conference.

But he said the government refused to deal with the regional autonomy movement mainly responsible for the closures of the Ras Lanuf, Es-Sider and Zueitina ports.

Its leader Ibrahim Jathran warned on Tuesday after a meeting of eastern tribal leaders that oil terminals would resume work only if the government met his demands for a greater share of Libya's oil wealth and more political power.

"We communicate only with the tribal elders," Mr Zeidan said when asked about Mr Jathran's conditions.

He also said that talks to end a strike at the southern El Sharara oilfield, which used to supply the 120,000-bpd Zawiya refinery, were continuing.

Pressure has been building on strikers paralysing oil and gas supplies across the desert nation, with power cuts also a result of the protests, according to the government.

Oil Minister Abdelbari al-Arusi said exports were only 110,000 bpd, compared with production of 250,000 bpd.

Of the total, 120,000 bpd were going to the Zawiya plant and 20,000 bpd to a refinery in Tobruk.

He said his ministry was ready to resume exports at the ports once strikers left the premises.

Western powers worry that Libya will slide into instability as the government struggles to rein in militias and tribes who helped oust Mr Gaddafi during the 2011 Nato-backed uprising but refuse to lay down their arms.

Mr Zeidan has been counting on rising public anger as the government warns that payment of public salaries will stop due to the loss of oil revenues if the blockages continue.

The Opec producer has lost almost 10 billion Libyan dinars (S$10.1 billion) due to the seizures since summer, state news agency Lana said.

Idris Abukhamada, head of the National Oil Guards and a member of the main tribe blocking the eastern ports, said he expected the terminals to reopen on Sunday as agreed.

He said Mr Jathran's conditions would not stand in the way. "The conditions are just cosmetic," he said, without elaborating.

Mr Abukhamada was appointed by the Tripoli government after Mr Jathran, the previous commander, defected in summer and seized the three ports with his heavily armed men.

Even if the ports reopen, more trouble looms because the oil workers' union threatened on Tuesday to close them again unless the government met their demands for higher pay.- Reuters

site_title: Taking risks with new artists
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Taking risks with new artists

From around the world, five collectors of South-east Asian art share their wisdom on how to build an art collection. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

MIKE AND LOU SAMSON

Both 43, Singapore PRs originally from the Philippines

He's a regional head of a bank, she runs an events firm

THEY started collecting art in 2000 when they had just moved to Singapore from the Philippines. At the time, they picked mainly colourful, pleasant-looking artworks with little historical or artistic value.

The turning point came in 2003 when they discovered an emerging group of Filipino artists who were creating art totally unlike what had been produced before in their country. "The paintings were figurative but austere, photographic-looking but were not photographs. They dealt with dark, urban themes like anonymity, displacement, dislocation - themes that frankly connected with us because we were expatriates in Singapore and we had both spent a few years studying in American universities before moving here," says Mike Samson, one half of the collector couple. "The Philippines is a Catholic country," adds his wife Lourdes, or Lou for short. "Very few people wanted to buy these works because the subject matter was so taboo. We bought them at low prices because the artists didn't have an audience yet."

But as it turned out, top auction houses Christie's and Sotheby's had also been closely watching the groundbreaking artists, which include Geraldine Javier, Nona Garcia and Yasmin Sison.

And when the two houses began to introduce their artworks in regional auctions, the prices "exploded", says Mrs Samson. "Many young art collectors were exposed to the same things that we were exposed to, and saw what we saw. So the works were snapped up and the prices shot up."

The "accidental collectors" admit that they were just "buying art that we liked". But their personal collection now boasts some 300 works by South-east Asian headliners like Jose Legaspi, Natee Utarit and Mariano Ching - not to mention, Garcia, Sisson and Javier.

Mr Samson says: "The lesson we learnt is, buy art from your own generation, because that's how you get the best works as well as a snapshot of your time.

"In the early years, we were buying - beside decorative art - art by famous artists from our parent's generation. But we quickly realised that we couldn't buy these artists' best works because they were (a) expensive, (b) already in our parent's generation's collections, or (c) in museums.

"So we focused on artists who were in the same age group as us. And that's worked out for us."

Final word of advice:

"Buy what you like; buy with your eyes, not your ears, because people will tell you stuff, but you should go with your heart. Also, art is very hard to sell, so if you're buying for flipping potential, it's a bad idea," says Mr Samson. Because artists of the likes of Garcia and Javier have gone up in value, the Samsons recommend looking at good Filipino artists whose prices are still in the affordable ranges. They are Lyle Buencamino, Norberto Roldan and Luis Santos.

Part of the Samsons' art collection is currently on show at Artspace@Helutrans, 39 Keppel Road, #02-03, Tanjong Pagar Distripark, from now till Dec 15. Opening hours: 11am to 7pm daily. Admission is free.

Call 6329-6847 for details.

site_title: Emerging markets down but not out
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Emerging markets down but not out

Opportunities next year but Europe and Japan deemed better bets for now

Published

Thu, Dec 12, 2013 · 10:00 PM

EMERGING-MARKET stocks may be down due to political uncertainties and Fed-tapering fears - but they are not out.

Market strategists say buying opportunities could come next year. But for now, there are better trades to be made in developed markets like Japan and Europe.

Schroders' head of emerging market equities Allan Conway said in a note: "The short-term outlook remains uncertain, so we believe it is too early to get super-bullish.

"Even though we would not rule out further weakness in the near term, a strong global emerging-markets rally at some point in 2014 is quite possible. Moreover, we are confident that returns over the next three years or so will be substantial, both in absolute terms and relative to developed markets."

He added: "An expanding emerging-market middle class continues to drive strong consumption, and fixed capital investment is growing due to the still-low levels of capital stock per capita. So in our opinion, the structural story remains intact."

Pascal Blanque, chief investment officer of asset manager Amundi, also sounded a word of caution about it being too early to enter emerging markets. He told The Business Times: "Most global portfolios are overweight in emerging markets, so it is too soon . . . We are neutral in our global asset allocation."

However, he warned against throwing the baby out with the bathwater. Amundi is positive on China stocks in the energy and telecommunications sectors and some banks, he said. Other than China, he said he had no emerging country preference, but that investors could look at technology and export-led sectors because these will drive growth.

Alain Bokobza, head of global asset allocation at Societe Generale cross-asset research, said in a briefing yesterday: "Do not catch a falling knife until taper."

Valuation measures show emerging-market equities have plunged from a 20 per cent premium to developed-market equities in the peak years of 2008 and 2010 to more than a 20 per cent discount now.

"There will be a time when cheap is cheap enough," he said, adding that he may make a "buy" call in the second quarter of 2014 or when emerging- market equities trade at a 30 per cent discount.

But there are still political uncertainties in the year ahead to paralyse decision-making, he said, citing the Indonesian elections in April, Indian elections in May and Brazilian elections in October.

Market strategists urged investors to be selective and to go only for emerging-market stocks with strong economic fundamentals.

If the US starts slowing down its financial-asset purchases next year, liquidity could flee emerging markets in a repeat of what happened in the middle of this year. India, Brazil, South Africa, Indonesia and Turkey - the so-called "Fragile Five" - experienced sharp selloffs because of their current-account deficits; the Indonesian currency is the worst-performing Asian currency this year, said Bank of America Merrill Lynch economist Chua Hak Bin.

Persistent current-account deficits in poorer countries are viewed as threatening their ability to repay their creditors. A current-account deficit can be caused by a country importing more than it exports (meaning it is uncompetitive), or having a low savings rate relative to what it invests.

Hot foreign money flowing into investment projects can lead to asset bubbles. A bursting of such a bubble can cause companies to default on their debt, as was the case during the 1997 Asian financial crisis. Similar fears after the US hinted at tapering its financial-asset purchases, together with slower expected growth in these economies, caused the "Fragile Five" to slide.

But Schroders' Mr Conway pointed out that these countries represent only 30 per cent of the MSCI Emerging Markets index. China, Korea, Taiwan and Russia - with their large current-account surpluses - represent half the index and were relatively unaffected by the post taper- fear selloff, he said.

Similarly, SocGen's Mr Bokobza said some countries are more vulnerable than others to a Fed taper. "Before stock picking is country picking," he said. Emerging markets have learnt their lesson since the Asian financial crisis and have much lower debt-to- GDP ratios now, he said.

But this is still not yet the time to buy China assets, he said, even though they are looking "super cheap" at 11/2 times book value, versus four times four years ago.

Observers have hailed China's recent Third Plenum policy meeting - which pledged a "decisive" role for markets - as a game changer. But for Mr Bokobza, China is losing competitiveness even as wage growth remains in double digits.

Liberalisation of markets will lead to competition from foreign companies, which shrinks profit margins. China is also not devaluing its currency to become more competitive, unlike Japan.

"I don't buy a dream. I buy facts," Mr Bokobza said.

He said eurozone equities are still attractively valued amid an economic recovery, and Japanese equities are set to soar again next year if its central bank announces even more money-printing for the market. A devalued yen will make Japan's exporters more competitive. The cost of currency hedging is not material, he said.

site_title: The world needs places of refuge
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The world needs places of refuge

Published

Tue, Dec 10, 2013 · 10:00 PM

ON MONDAY, newly elected International Salvage Union (ISU) president Leendert Muller told journalists in London that salvors strongly believed there must be progress on the issue of "places of refuge". These are sheltered coastal areas of water where salvors can take a ship in difficulties and carry out emergency repairs and cargo transfers.

Mr Muller said that taking a ship to a place of refuge "carries some risk of pollution to the nearby coastline if the condition of the ship gets worse, but that risk is even greater in the open sea or at a more dangerous coastal location".

He continued: "The problem is that too many states refuse to accept their obligations and refuse to grant a place of refuge. Our members have frequently had to battle the authorities to find a safe place to bring a casualty."

This issue has been in news again recently. One reason for that is the outcome of the Prestige trial in Spain, where denial of a place of refuge was a central factor.

Convicted for disobedience

Tanker owners body Intertanko's reaction was probably typical of that of the wider shipping industry. It said the tanker industry had cause to celebrate that, 11 years after the event, the master of the Prestige, Apostolos Mangouras, and the vessel's chief engineer Nikolaos Argyropoulos, had finally been acquitted by the Spanish courts of criminal damage to the environment. But it was deeply disappointed at his criminal conviction for disobedience.

Also acquitted was José Luis López Sors González, former head of Spain's merchant marine department - which means the Spanish state will not be held responsible for the disaster. The courts failed to find anyone guilty of directly causing the disaster in November 2002 when the laden tanker Prestige broke up and sank off the Spanish coast, spilling some 50,000 tonnes of oil.

Intertanko noted that Captain Mangouras was forced by the Spanish authorities, against his judgement, to take a series of actions that resulted in the damaged tanker being taken out to sea in appalling conditions.

There are more recent examples of salvors being unable to take casualties to places of refuge. At Monday's press lunch, Mr Muller said: "Last year, for example, the containership MSC Flaminia suffered a severe fire in the eastern Atlantic. Salvors stabilised the situation but then had real difficulty bringing the vessel into a European port. Likewise, the Stolt Valor, a chemical tanker that suffered a fire, was refused entry to numerous ports in the Middle East."

"The frustration," he said, "is that there is already a helpful framework of international and regional regulations that effectively require states to offer a place of refuge to a casualty. We know it is politically difficult to voluntarily allow a damaged ship into home waters but the alternative - as was seen with the Prestige - can be serious pollution over a much wider area."

A couple of months ago, ISU published a position paper on the issue and started discussions with the shipowners' International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) and others to explore ways of making progress on this issue.

In the paper, ISU says it wishes to see wider adoption by coastal states of simple, robust, "single-point" command-and-control models similar to the UK's, where an industry expert known as the Secretary of State's Representative for Maritime Salvage and Intervention (SOSREP) takes all the decisions.

Yesterday, in London, ISU's executive committee discussed the issue with the UK's SOSREP. Today, an alliance of ISU, ICS and the International Union of Marine Insurance (IUMI) is to have a meeting to plan how to convince coastal states of the need for a system that provides places of refuge and, ultimately, protects their coasts.

It is hard to be optimistic, given the track record, but this is a cause that deserves general support. It is in nobody's interest to let another Prestige disaster happen.
