site_title: S'pore ranks 7th in Forbes 'best for business' list
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore ranks 7th in Forbes 'best for business' list

Published

Fri, Dec 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

SINGAPORE has fallen three spots to seventh place in Forbes' 2013 list of best countries for business, weighed down by a poor-performing stock market this year and a continued low ranking in personal freedom.

While it came in tops in metrics such as trade freedom, investor protection, anti-corruption measures and being relatively free of the burdens of red tape and taxes, it ranked 60th for market performance and 91st for personal freedom in a field of 145 countries and territories.

In other areas - property rights, innovation, technology, and monetary freedom - it made it into the top 20.

Its main stock market index, the Straits Times Index (STI), climbed 7.6 per cent in the 12 months leading up to Nov 20, the cut-off date for the period Forbes measured market performance.

Year-to-date, the STI is in the red, down slightly at yesterday's close of 3,114.17. A handful of factors caused this decline, most recently the October penny counter saga, which wiped a sizeable amount of funds from the market.

Investors' anticipation of a Fed tapering of its quantitative-easing also sent the index to year-lows in late August.

A slew of property cooling measures and stricter bank-lending regulations announced this year, compounded with weak corporate earnings, especially in Q3, further crimped the market's performance, said Voyage Research's deputy research head Ng Kian Teck.

"The (weightage of the) three local banks make up 31 per cent of the STI; real estate makes up another 10.5 per cent. I think it is safe to say the new government measures had an impact on STI returns," he said.

Ireland, sixth last year, took the top spot as the most business-friendly country. It is the first time that it has done so since Forbes began compiling this ranking in 2006.

Its pole position may surprise some, given that it had required a US$113 billion bailout package just three years ago, in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis. But it appears to have turned crisis into opportunity: a significant drop in nominal wages from 2008 to 2011 and a stubbornly high unemployment rate (and thus larger labour pool) have attracted and sped up investments from foreign companies between 2008 and last year. Its stock market has been on fire, with its stock exchange index boasting a 44-per-cent return in the 12 months through Nov 20.

New Zealand was dethroned from first place and now ranks second. Forbes said: "The US$170 billion economy is the smallest of the top 10, but one of the fastest growing, with gross domestic product up 2.5 per cent last year."

Hong Kong took third place for the second year running, although its economic growth last year was slower than in 2011. Denmark and Sweden rounded up the top five.

Meanwhile, the US continued its four-year slide to 14th spot from 12th last year and second in 2009. Forbes said: "The US gets dinged for the Federal Reserve's easy-money programme, which has distorted prices and risked long-term inflation." This consigned the country to 80th place out of 145 countries and territories for monetary freedom.

Stephen Barnes returns to SIA as CFO on Jan 20

Published

Fri, Dec 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE new chief financial officer at Singapore Airlines will be Stephen Barnes, who will leave his post as senior director of portfolio management at aircraft-leasing firm Guggenheim Aviation Partners.

It will be a return to SIA for the 54-year-old, who was with Singapore's national carrier from June 2001 to October 2008, his last-held position being divisional vice-president for treasury and structured finance, said SIA.

Mr Barnes takes over on Jan 20, replacing current CFO Chan Hon Chew, who is joining Keppel Corp.

In a statement to the Singapore Exchange yesterday, SIA said that Mr Barnes possesses the qualifications, experience and credentials necessary to fulfil the role.

"Currently in the aircraft-leasing industry, he has over 30 years of experience as a finance professional, and has held key leadership positions in industries ranging from banking to fund management."

SIA noted his previous seven-year stint with it, and said that he followed up his time in SIA with a move to Guggenheim Aviation Partners, where his roles included being director of marketing for the Asia-Pacific and senior director of finance.

Guggenheim Aviation Partners supports its US affiliate, asset manager Guggenheim Aviation Partners LLC, in acquiring new and used commercial planes for leasing to airlines and cargo operators.

Mr Chan, who was with SIA for more than a decade, has been the airline's senior vice-president of finance since 2006.

He is set to start as CFO at Keppel on Feb 1, with the current CFO there, Loh Chin Hua, being promoted to chief executive officer.

On Nov 15, SIA had announced that Mr Chan had resigned to "pursue other career opportunities" without announcing a replacement.

Shares in SIA closed yesterday at $10.22, down 20 cents.

site_title: Mars outing unravels and crash-lands
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mars outing unravels and crash-lands

Irish director Ruair Robinson's The Last Days on Mars is one small step on Mars but one giant misstep for box-office takings, writes DYLAN TAN

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THERE'S probably only one reason to catch The Last Days on Mars - to satisfy your own curiosity.

It was screened in the Directors' Fortnight section at Cannes earlier this year alongside Ilo Ilo and Irish director Ruair Robinson was up against Anthony Chen for the Camera d'Or award. No prize for guessing who won.

The Last Days on Mars has plenty of indie heart with its modest production budget and a great cast; but despite Robinson's best efforts to reach for the stars in his debut feature, the film somehow crash-lands mid-course and leaves the audience lost in space.

Based on prolific English writer Sydney J Bounds' 1975 short story, The Animators, it has an interesting premise, not unlike the one about the homesick spaceman who wants to go home in Duncan Jones's excellent minimalist sci-fi drama Moon (2009).

But despite a promising start, The Last Days on Mars abruptly goes into B-grade territory as Robinson trades in the claustrophobic tension he builds up in the first act for cheap zombie scares in the second.

Liev Schreiber plays Vincent, one of the crew members of an eight-person team stationed on Mars. After a six-month tour of duty, they are all weary and ready to head home.

With less than 24 hours to go before they get picked up, everybody gets busy packing. Except Marko (Goran Kostic) who earlier discovered some signs of life on the Red Planet but has chosen to keep mum about it for his own personal glory.

Disobeying orders, he heads out for one last unauthorised mission to collect samples but gets swallowed up by the ground instead.

The incident causes panic as the team sets out to recover his body. Before they can find it, another member goes missing and suddenly, The Last Days on Mars turns into a full-blown outer space zombie flick with Vincent and the rest of his colleagues trying to stay alive for as long as they can.

It's here the film lets its audience down. Instead of developing his characters, screenwriter Clive Dawson conveniently kills them off one by one as Robinson rehashes Ridley Scott's Alien and John Carpenter's The Thing. At just over 90 minutes, The Last Days on Mars has a compact runtime but still feels draggy because genre fans would have seen it all before.

It's a missed opportunity for Robinson who should have turned this into a character drama with a small serving of horror on the side instead of trying to mimic a studio creature feature.

That way, he could have also realised the full potential of his cast - many such as Schreiber and Elias Koteas are great character actors by nature - instead of them just becoming monster feed.

But the director does a great job of transforming Jordan into Mars with the help of his cinematographer Robbie Ryan and production designer Jon Henson so the film looks well-crafted and never cheap despite its modest budget. Max Richter's atmospheric score is also haunting and effective in inducing goosebumps.

A little more originality is probably all it takes for The Last Days on Mars to go a long way instead of it feeling like a real drag.

C

site_title: Hip finds in street-art central
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hip finds in street-art central

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Alternative London Walking Tour

(Pay what you like)

Start and finish near Spitalfields Market. Check out

alternativeldn.com

for details

IF - like me - you've always been suspicious of street art and remain unconvinced by the rise of UK-based graffiti artist Banksy, then it might do you good to go on the excellent Alternative London Walking Tour.

It's a far cry from the august museums and chi-chi gallery scene, but the tour opens your eyes to the vitality and importance of street art, not just in giving artists a chance to display their creativity but also in reviving the economic fortunes of certain areas. Take Brick Lane, for instance, which is one of the poorest parts of London. When the shop owners decided to allow street artists to paint graffiti on the exterior walls of their shops, Brick Lane became street-art central. It drew businesses, local visitors and tourists which, in turn, led to a jump in real estate prices as wealthier residents wanted to move there.

The politics and economics of gentrification aside, the art itself is pretty fantastic. Some of the street art is so subtle or small, you'd have to look very hard to find it - like the realistic-looking but fake road signs that make anti-government statements, or the funny figurines on top of some lamp-posts.

Meanwhile, the larger wall displays by artists such as Martin Ron and Ben Eine are simply stunning. They make you go: "Banksy who?"

site_title: Blend of tradition and modernity
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blend of tradition and modernity

Jaime Ee

Published

Fri, Dec 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

AT 36 years old, a little closer to civilisation and with in-room showers (and private baths in some rooms), Ryokan Tanigawa is a baby compared to Chojukan, but what it lacks in age it makes up for with a happy blend of tradition and modernity.

Also in Minakami - you only need to take one bus from Jomo Kogen to Minakami station and someone from the ryokan will pick you up - Ryokan Tanigawa is a homey, unpretentious getaway run by the Kubo family who also owns the upmarket Relaix and Chateaux property Bettei Senjyuan. Just slightly more expensive than Hoshi, which is priced around 20,000 yen (S$245.50) per person, Ryokan Tanigawa is an affordable way to cap off a visit to Hoshi while still enjoying the spectacular mountain scenery.

Unlike other ryokans, what you see isn't necessarily what you get. As in, while it looks like a regular ryokan, there are little design touches that show off owner Tomio Kubo's keen eye for detail. The trained horticulturist and second generation ryokan owner created a Japanese garden from scratch on Tanigawa's grounds,and he was the first to replace the wooden floors of the dressing area of each room with tatami mats. He was also the first to use hinoki wood for the baths instead of rocks - a practice that has since been adopted by other ryokans.

Apart from all the creature comforts, food also gets extra attention at Tanigawa. Breakfast and dinner are usually packaged into the price at any Japanese inn, and tend to be pretty straightforward affairs, but Tanigawa offers extra elaborate menus that maximise the fresh produce from the surrounding area. If you spend your day schlepping around the neighbourhood to find the best camera angle for the stunning Mount Tanigawa which the ryokan is named after, you'll more than welcome this splendid repast. After which a soak in the joint-soothing alkaline waters that fills your private bath guarantees you a blissful stay.

site_title: WTO should aim for small successes in Bali
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

WTO should aim for small successes in Bali

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

LONGSTANDING talks for a global trade deal are underway again, this time in Bali, to attempt to seal a multilateral agreement that has eluded negotiators for a dozen years now. The negotiations - which began in Doha, Qatar in 2001 - have seen the 159 member countries of the World Trade Organization (WTO) bicker over achieving a trade liberalisation pact. Two years ago, countries watered down the initial ambitious pact to cut tariffs on goods and services in an effort to nail down an agreement. This is the right approach. But it has not yielded a pact which brings all 159 members onboard a single liberalisation regime.

The ninth WTO Ministerial Conference in Bali presents perhaps the best opportunity yet to seal some kind of deal. It is important - for the global economy and indeed for the WTO itself. The failure of past attempts to strike a global trade deal has seen a proliferation of regional and bilateral trade pacts in the last decade. Negotiated between groups of countries with congruent interests, such deals have been easier to hammer out, and their success has questioned the need for a multilateral deal. But such a deal is still vitally needed.

The irony of the "spaghetti bowl" of regional and bilateral trade agreements is that their proliferation erodes the exclusive benefits that countries accrue from their trade partners. For instance, Country A is extended certain trade benefits by Country B when it signs a trade deal with the latter, but this benefit is eroded if Country B inks similar agreements with Countries C, D and E - which is what has been happening. After a point, it makes increasing sense for everyone to seek a multilateral deal; it's not only simpler for businesses, but also results in wider trade creation and economic benefits.

But the lack of progress on the global trade deal has dented the credibility of the WTO, which it needs to salvage to retain its relevance as an institution and to keep hopes of a multilateral trade deal alive.

In Bali, the WTO should focus on a series of plurilateral agreements which would allow groups of countries to voluntarily agree to new rules on specific trade issues (as with the information technology agreement at the WTO's inaugural Singapore Ministerial Conference in 1996) rather than chasing a full-blown multilateral agreement where all member countries have to agree.

In recent years, India (in particular) has been a stumbling block to a multilateral deal due to its insistence on maintaining its food subsidy programme. It might be more expedient for the WTO to focus on other less contentious areas - clean technology, and selected services, for instance, in addition to trade facilitation - so that there is some movement forward.

After 12 years of failed negotiations, it seems clear that the Doha Round of trade talks would be very difficult to wrap up in a comprehensive fashion. But incremental successes are possible. These would add up and help restore faith in the multilateral system - and perhaps eventually lead to a comprehensive trade deal a few years down the road.

Stay in a Victorian townhouse

Published

Cranley Hotel

10 Bina Gardens,

London SW5 0LA

Rooms from £138

Visit

cranleyhotel.com

IF you haven't booked a hotel yet, you should consider the Cranley Hotel, a quaint and cosy boutique hotel run by Singapore's KOP Group.

It comprises three Victorian townhouses in the posh South Kensington area. It boasts traditional English-style rooms with four-poster beds and classic furnishings. Nearly all of the furniture are antique and the artworks are unique - which explains why no two rooms look alike. KOP Group, which runs luxury developments such as Hamilton Scotts and The Ritz-Carlton Residences Singapore, took over from its previous owners in Nov 2011. The rooms were refurbished and occupancy doubled to approximately 90 per cent.

The hotel rates are competitive considering its location, with room prices starting at £138 (S$283). It is close to major museums such as the Victoria & Albert Museum, as well as the Saatchi Gallery. The hotel's nearest tube station is Gloucester Road, which is five stops away from Piccadilly Circus.

Because the hotel is relatively small with less than 40 rooms, the staff remember all the guests' names. Not surprisingly, it receives many returning guests.

If there is one gripe this writer has, it's that the hotel is initially hard to find because it's not located on the main road.

So be sure to get precise directions on how to get there from Gloucester Station - if you're taking the train from the airport to avoid the crazy traffic into central London.

From rock angst to fairy dust

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

The Light Princess

National Theatre

From now till Feb 2014

Tickets from

nationaltheatre.org.uk

IF you're looking for something Christmassy to do with the kids, you might want to consider The Light Princess, the new children's fairy-tale musical with music and lyrics by former rock goddess Tori Amos.

Amos was once famous for her angry rock anthems about the injustices wrought on her by the men in her life. But since getting married and having a child, her music has mellowed and softened considerably.

The Light Princess is based on a Victorian fairy tale by George Macdonald. It tells of a princess who becomes completely weightless and starts to float when she refuses to cry at her mother's funeral.

A turning point, however, comes when her kingdom goes to war with another and she is ordered to lead the army. Amos's music is intricate and melodic, but not terribly memorable. What's worth writing home about is the extraordinary direction by Marianne Elliott, who also helmed the hit musicals War Horse and The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time. In her hands, The Light Princess is a wondrous flight of fantasy, with enchanting sets and costumes. Above all, the sheer technical genius of making the princess float in the air throughout the musical is something to behold.

Because it's showing at the National Theatre, tickets are also considerably cheaper than most musicals in London, with ticket prices ranging from £12 to £50 (S$24.60 to $102.60).

site_title: China feeling pinch of credit crunch
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China feeling pinch of credit crunch

It's due to deliberate central bank policy shift to rein in credit growth, survey says

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

CHINA'S effort to rebalance its economy has a mirror image in finance and it's called credit crunch.

This week, the global industry grouping for finance professionals, the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA), declared that "the long-predicted credit crunch in China has well and truly arrived", as it reported the tightest supply of growth capital in at least two years and sharp falls in business investment in capital and staff.

ACCA's stance is supported by its findings from a new quarterly Global Economic Conditions Survey, the world's largest regular economic survey of accountants. It asserts that "China's credit crunch bites in the third quarter, but nightmare scenarios have yet to play out".

It notes: "The slowdown in China is far from over, as credit rationing and fears about private and public sector debt have continued to damage the Chinese recovery."

Emmanouil Schizas, ACCA senior economic analyst, says China's liquidity crunch is a side-effect of a deliberate policy shift, since this summer, by its central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), to rein in credit growth and reallocate funds away from shadow banking, in addition to using it as a test of its liquidity tools.

"The PBOC seem to regard it as tough medicine for the banking system, and they are trying to manage the side-effects," Mr Schizas says, adding that the central bank appears fully aware of these side-effects, including the inevitable slower economic growth and the impact of credit tightening on small and medium enterprises which depends more on shadow banking than their bigger state-owned peers.

"The authorities are aware of this and have been pressuring banks to direct more funds towards SMEs for years now. Unfortunately, this rebalancing cannot happen as quickly as the reduction of credit, so we will be interested to see how the authorities intend to compensate for the loss of credit to SMEs," he adds.

Mr Schizas suggests that Chinese authorities have a higher threshold of tolerance for small business failures than its western counterparts and will not be rushed in their response.

"A banking crisis is unlikely but banks remaining damaged in the long term is perhaps not so impossible," Mr Schizas says. "Historically, China has previous experience of successfully clearing up bad debts but this took over a decade and a very substantial amount of money."

Credit crunch has become a recurring theme in the Chinese banking system. Following a severe crunch in June, authorities allowed credit to expand in August and September only to tighten the screw again in the next two months, with overnight interbank lending rate shooting up to 3.93 per cent on Nov 22, higher even than in June. Liquidity in the banking system has taken a breather recently after an injection of funds from the central bank.

Broadly, however, liquidity remains tight outside the traditional banking system, as evident in the high yields offered by Chinese banks for their wealth management products, a major line of business in the shadow banking world. Yields for these products rose to as much as 5.37 per cent on average in the last week of November, setting a yearly record, according to statistics published by industry website yinhang.com.

Louis Kuijs, chief China economist at RBS, says he expects China will maintain a firmer stance in the coming quarters. "The tightening does affect some banks' ability to lend, mainly some smaller and mid-sized banks that fund themselves via the interbank market. It does not affect much the other, often larger banks which fund themselves via deposits," Mr Kuijs says.

One thing that policymakers could do is to ease up on its credit quotas to these affected banks as a way to ensure bank lending continues to expand at a reasonably pace despite a tight interbank market. The RBS team believes "as long as core bank lending continues to expand at a reasonably solid pace, the impact on economic growth of a reduction of (shadow banking) expansion centred around lower non-bank financing can be moderate".

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Telenor's entry gives mobile boost to SPH-linked 701Search

Norwegian telco has over 150m mobile customers globally

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

ONLINE marketplace media firm 701Search is set to make further inroads in the mobile space now that Norway's Telenor ASA has come onboard as a new shareholder.

"In some of our key countries, almost 50 per cent of our users are accessing the classifieds through mobile. So mobile is getting more and more important in this game," said Alan Chan, CEO of Singapore Press Holdings, whose wholly owned subsidiary SPH Interactive International (SPHI) owns a third of 701Search.

"We really welcome Telenor's participation because as a mobile operator, they can bring us perspective of the mobile world," Mr Chan added. He was speaking at a media briefing yesterday.

On Tuesday, Telenor finalised the acquisition of a one-third stake in 701Search. Through its unit, Telenor Communications II, it bought an equal number of shares from the existing shareholders - SPHI and Norway's Schibsted Classified Media AS - as well as subscribed to additional shares in the joint- venture firm. The three partners now each own one-third of 701Search.

Telenor has more than 150 million mobile customers globally, the bulk of whom are in Asia. It has a presence in Malaysia, Thailand, Bangladesh, Pakistan, India and Myanmar.

701Search occupies the same geographical orbit, operating online classified companies such as Mudah.my in Malaysia, Berniaga.com in Indonesia and Ayosdito.ph in the Philippines.

Where expansion of 701Search is concerned, Mr Chan said yesterday that the unit "will keep looking at various countries in the region".

"We are always prepared to explore new markets. If it works, then we will push on. If it doesn't work, then we will quickly shift our strategy," he added.

Now, Telenor will bring the knowledge of its own customers in the market to 701Search's table, said Rolv-Erik Spilling, CEO and head of Telenor Digital, yesterday.

Its experience working with other Internet players will also come in handy, with practices such as service bundling and preconfiguration of mobile handsets as possibilities. "When you make it very easy to access, you get more traction on the service," Mr Spilling said.

At the same time, for Telenor, the deal represents a prime way to break into the classifieds markets in the region. Several years ago, it had attempted to do just that in Malaysia on its own but did not succeed, according to Mr Spilling.

"It's almost an art to do good classified sites," he said yesterday. "Now we see that, being part of this initiative, and we will learn a lot from our customers.

"We are certainly entering a partnership which brings value from a usage and customer insight perspective."

London votes for foreign property-investor tax

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] The London Assembly passed a motion welcoming a possible move by the government to bring in capital-gains tax on foreign investors selling a home in the city.

The motion was passed on Wednesday with 13 votes in favour and six against, according to an e-mailed statement by the 25-member assembly, whose main function is to hold London's mayor to account.

"Londoners' right to own a decent home must be put before speculative investors in London's property market," assembly member Tom Copley from the Labour Party, in opposition nationally, said in the statement. "London property is becoming a global reserve currency for people to keep their money and to make money out of London property."

Prices for luxury homes have soared in recent years as the debt crisis in the euro region and uprisings across North Africa have made London property a haven for international investors. The government's Help to Buy programme has also fuelled concerns about a potential bubble.

Bank of England governor Mark Carney took steps to dampen a house-price boom last week by ending incentives for mortgage lending in the bank's Funding for Lending Scheme.

Sky News television reported a month ago that the government is considering extending capital-gains tax to foreign investors. Treasury Minister Sajid Javid indicated last month that an announcement was likely in Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne's Autumn Statement to Parliament late yesterday. - Bloomberg

site_title: Westfield to control NY's WTC retail space
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Westfield to control NY's WTC retail space

With this stake, its investment there will exceed US$1.4b

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Westfield Group, Australia's biggest shopping mall operator, will invest US$800 million to take full control of the retail space at New York's World Trade Center.

The company agreed to buy Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's 50 per cent stake in the retail part of lower Manhattan's World Trade Center site, bringing its investment in the property to more than US$1.4 billion, the Sydney-based company and the Port Authority said in separate statements on Wednesday.

The group, which also said it plans to split its domestic and international businesses, is building on that separation with the World Trade Center deal as it bets on faster growth outside its home country. The US will account for two-thirds of properties managed by the new global business, Westfield Corp, and income from the assets will grow by as much as 6 per cent in 2014, it said.

"This is a great addition, and it's the type of asset and location that sits neatly with Westfield's strategy," said Tony Sherlock, Sydney-based head of property research at Morningstar Australasia Pty.

"There's not much risk to this project, and if you want valuation upside, you want it on your balance sheet, not someone else's," he said.

Westfield first acquired a 99-year lease interest in the retail concourse at the original trade centre six weeks before it was destroyed in the Sept 11, 2001, attacks, and sold it back to the Port Authority in December 2003. The group agreed in July 2011 to pay US$612.5 million to take a half-stake in a joint venture with the Port Authority to develop the centre. The retail complex is scheduled to open in 2015.

The project will encompass about 365,000 square feet of retail space, with another 90,000 sq ft to be added in future, according to the statement.

The Port Authority owns the 16-acre (six-hectare) site. It includes the 72-storey 4 World Trade Center, developed by Larry Silverstein, which opened last month; 1 World Trade Center, the Western Hemisphere's tallest skyscraper, set to open in January; the 9/11 memorial, a 9/11 museum, a performing arts centre and a mass-transit hub designed by Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava.

Westfield's investment will allow the Port Authority to "refocus agency resources on our core transportation mission", chairman David Samson said in the statement.

On Wednesday, Westfield, which jointly owns malls in Australia and New Zealand with Westfield Retail Trust, proposed combining their stakes to create a new company called Scentre Group.

Its overseas operations, in the United States, the United Kingdom and Italy, would become a separate entity, Westfield Corp, it said.

The move advances its attempts to distance itself from Australia and New Zealand, where it expects to see the slowest growth this year of all its markets. Westfield spun off half of its Australian and New Zealand malls into Westfield Retail Trust in 2010, and billionaire co-founder Frank Lowy and his family sold their 7.1 per cent stake in the trust in February.

Mr Lowy is Australia's fourth-richest individual with a net worth of US$5.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Westfield Corp will have a US$1.2 billion share of US$1.4 billion of projects under construction, including the World Trade Center, the company said. It also plans US$9 billion of future projects including malls in London and Milan, it said.

In the US, where the group forecasts growth of as much as 5 per cent in 2014, retail sales in October recorded their biggest gain in three months, while a private gauge on consumer confidence rose in November from a month earlier, beating a preliminary reading.

Westfield's acquisition of the 50 per cent stake in the World Trade Center's retail space represents a 30 per cent premium in value for the authority, according to Wednesday's statement.

"In addition, the Port Authority will have the potential to receive an additional one-time payment from Westfield within the first five years after the retail grand opening, should Westfield exceed certain agreed-upon return thresholds," the agency said. - Bloomberg

site_title: Median COV for resale flats at lowest in 4 years
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Median COV for resale flats at lowest in 4 years

Nov figure of $8,000 lowest since July '09; 97 units sold below valuation: SRX

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The market for Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale flats continued to weaken last month, with median cash-over-valuations (COVs) falling to their lowest level in more than four years.

Median COVs fell 30.1 per cent to $8,000 in November, according to flash estimates from the Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX), from $11,444 the month before.

This is the first time that the cash premium fell below $10,000 since July 2009. COVs have consistently declined through 2013 from a peak of $35,000 in January.

"COV continued to fall and we are seeing more flats exchanging hands for zero COV or below valuation," said Eugene Lim, key executive officer at ERA Realty.

Overall, on the month, SRX expects an estimated 1,051 resale flats to have been sold in November, down from the 1,187 units the month before.

SRX data showed that 97 resale flats sold last month were transacted below their valuation price, higher than the 82 units in October. Sengkang, Choa Chu Kang, and Jurong West had the most resale HDB flats sold below valuation in November.

The overall HDB resale price index in November dipped 0.6 per cent from October to 146.9 - the lowest level since last September.

Mr Lim attributed the weak performance overall to a tighter mortgage servicing ratio, as well as other policies such as allowing singles to buy Build-to-Order (BTO) flats, a three-year wait before new permanent residents can buy a resale flat and an increasing supply of new flats.

In the private residential sector, resale activity was lacklustre as well.

Resale prices for non-landed private residential units are estimated to have fallen 1.5 per cent from the previous month to 171.5 in November - which would make it the third straight month of decline.

"Prices have continued to soften and will continue to soften with all the property cooling measures snowballing and upcoming supply," said Mr Lim.

All three regions saw price drops, led a by 2 per cent decline in the Core Central Region, followed by a 0.9 per cent dip for Outside Central Region and a 0.7 per cent loss in Rest of Central Region.

An estimated 387 non-landed homes were moved last month, 22.9 per cent lower than the 502 units in October.

site_title: 647 StanChart clients' data stolen
content:
647 StanChart clients' data stolen

Info found on James Raj's laptop; MAS may act against bank

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The monthly statements of 647 of Standard Chartered Bank's private bank clients have been discovered on a computer belonging to alleged hacker James Raj Arokiasamy.

The police revealed last night that they had found the stolen data on the 35-year-old's laptop after arresting him last month and charging him with hacking a number of official websites.

The bank statements, which were for February this year, were stolen in March from one of the servers at Fuji Xerox Singapore, which prints these statements for StanChart's private bank clients.

To be a private banking client, StanChart customers must have at least US$2 million in assets managed by the bank. The monthly statements include information such as their account numbers, account balances and transaction details.

In a statement yesterday, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said it was considering whether to take regulatory action against StanChart, even as it noted that the theft - believed to be the first such case here - was an isolated incident.

How the bank statements ended up in James Raj's laptop is unknown as police investigations are still ongoing. As of last night, he has not been charged for anything related to this incident.

StanChart, which made a police report on Monday, said that no unauthorised transactions had been found as a result of the theft. The bank also informed MAS that the incident had not compromised the bank's own IT systems or infrastructure.

StanChart has since contacted the affected clients "as a precautionary measure", adding that none of its wholesale banking clients, SME and retail customers have been affected.

Speaking at a hastily convened media briefing last night, StanChart chief executive officer Ray Ferguson issued an apology to all the bank's customers.

"The confidentiality and privacy of our clients are of paramount importance to us, and we take this incident very seriously. Customer data protection is our responsibility and we sincerely apologise to all our customers and specifically to our private bank clients who have been affected," he said.

Fuji Xerox CEO Bert Wong said the theft was the first in his company's history. "We share (StanChart's) concerns on the theft of information on the system, and deeply regret the incident. There was unauthorised access by a third party to the server, dedicated to Standard Chartered Private Bank, in a standalone printing facility," he said.

Despite Fuji being ignorant of the theft for eight months, Mr Wong said yesterday there has been no impact on the data of customers on any other systems of the company.

In response to separate queries by The Business Times, Fuji Xerox Global Services associate director Paul Han revealed that the data theft took place in March

. The company, however, only found out about the incident when StanChart informed it on Nov 28.

"We took action as soon as we were alerted to this. A professional forensic team has been engaged to conduct a thorough review of the unauthorised access and we have since heightened our vigilance and strengthened our security infrastructure," said Mr Han. Bound by client confidentiality, he could not say if other banks were among its clients. He would only say that "no other clients are at risk".

It is understood that Fuji Xerox Singapore is also contracted to print statements for one other non-bank financial institution (FI).

In its statement, MAS noted that, globally, FIs have been facing an "increasing number and variety" of cyber threats. "MAS takes a serious view of such threats and has stringent requirements in place for FIs to protect the security of their IT systems and confidentiality of client data," said the central bank.

These include regular vulnerability assessments, penetration tests and external audits of the effectiveness of their controls. These requirements, said MAS, apply regardless of whether such client data is processed in-house or at third-party providers.

The banking regulator added that this recent theft "underscores the need for heightened vigilance in financial institutions, including close management of risks pertaining to service providers".

MAS has since reminded all FIs to heighten their vigilance to safeguard their IT systems and customer information, including controls at third-party service providers. MAS also said it was paying "special supervisory attention" to FIs' compliance with its requirements for IT outsourcing.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Plotting to make you squirm in your seat

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IF your year-end plans don't involve a trip to London, don't fret - West End is coming to Singapore's Kallang Theatre, by way of The Woman in Black.

The acclaimed two-man play which opens next week is based on the novel of the same name by English author Susan Hill in 1983. A film adaptation starring Daniel Radcliffe was released early last year.

The Woman In Black is a spine-chilling thriller that frightens not with special effects but with its story. An old man named Arthur Kipps recounts a supernatural experience in his life to a young actor. It took place 30 years before when he was a junior solicitor attending a funeral, at which he saw the eponymous apparition.

Though director Robin Herford, who has been with the show since it started in 1987, refrains from revealing any more of the plot, he wants people to know that The Woman In Black is far more than just your run-of-the-mill ghost story.

"People say it's a horror show, but it's not. It is a human tragedy. There is no blood. It's not about alien forces of evil from outer space or zombies. This is a human story and if you have a human sensibility you will appreciate it," explains Herford, who will also be playing the role of Kipps during the show's run in Singapore.

According to him, the show is made scary not by any special effects or computer generated images, but by simple tried-and-tested theatre tricks such as lighting, sound and a manipulation of the audiences' imaginations. "I think this show demonstrates exactly what it is that's so special about live theatre," says Herford. Being in the same room as the actors gives an immediacy and an impact that you don't get with an image projected onto a flat wall. You can't just shut your eyes and put your fingers in your ears. You're captive in the same room with them. And it's not just what happens on stage, the whole auditorium is part of this show, so you can never sit quite comfortably in your seat."

site_title: EasyJet to expand market share in France, Germany
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

EasyJet to expand market share in France, Germany

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] EasyJet, Europe's No 2 discount airline, is consolidating its position in France and Germany even as full-service rivals Air France-KLM Group and Deutsche Lufthansa rush to establish their own low-cost footprint.

The UK carrier aims to expand its market share in France by one percentage point each year from 14 per cent today. A new base in Hamburg will boost the number of aircraft flying out of Germany, Europe's biggest economy, to 12 by next year, by which time the carrier will run 243 routes to and from the two countries.

"We are shaking the tree," French regional director Francoise Bacchetta said in an interview at EasyJet's headquarters in Luton near London. Consumers have "long-term habits from dealing with the same operator".

Mounting losses have forced network airlines to slash jobs and shift short-haul operations to stand-alone units including Transavia, Hop! and Germanwings.

EasyJet chief executive officer Carolyn McCall has intensified efforts to siphon off business passengers by offering allocated seats, flexible tickets, fast-tracking and higher frequencies on key routes.

Her strategy has been rewarded with a 78 per cent stock gain this year, the second-best annual return since the company first sold shares to the public more than a decade ago.

Some 11 million of EasyJet's 58 million customers in fiscal 2013 booked business-class seats. Ms McCall estimates that about 86 million short-haul passengers flying from Europe's top 20 airports each year could migrate to discount from network carriers.

EasyJet today has 960 employees and 25 aircraft based in France, up from five jets in 2002. The carrier became the largest operator this year at Nice on the French Riviera. The airline is among the top two operators at eight out of 10 of France's biggest airports, Mr Bacchetta said, adding that Air France still controls 40 per cent of the market.

"The thing is in France, there is no French low-cost airline, so we try to be the French low-cost airline," Mr Bacchetta said. "We saw the opportunity in the regions especially."

Air France-KLM is considering reducing frequencies, shutting routes and adjusting prices for flights from provincial bases in southern France created just a year ago.

"Given the amount of disruption and seemingly interminable adjustments to the short-haul strategies of both Air France-KLM and Lufthansa, EasyJet should be able to continue to build out its fleet and route growth in France and Germany," Investec's James Hollins said.

France lags behind the rest of Europe, with the low-cost proportion standing at 26 per cent versus an average of 42 per cent across the continent, Mr Bacchetta said. EasyJet operates 27 domestic routes today, competing with Air France's regional unit Hop!, which was created last year from three disparate airlines and offers point-to-point services with a fleet of 98 regional planes.

Air France is also switching services to the Transavia low-cost subsidiary created by KLM, which provides non-hub flights using Boeing 737s to transport mainly leisure passengers.

In Germany, where Lufthansa is ceding all short-haul flights outside the Frankfurt and Munich hubs to its Germanwings subsidiary, EasyJet is the fifth-largest carrier, with 3.5 per cent market share. By the end of next year, the airline will employ close to 500 people in Germany, regional director Thomas Haagensen said.

"Our customers are used to comparing prices, are used to the low-cost concept, so it's almost easier to grow from that basis," Mr Haagensen said.

Germanwings has responded to the low-cost challenge, saying last month that it will add six destinations from Hamburg from the middle of next year, including Rome and Toulouse. EasyJet in turn is targeting corporate passengers with refined schedules and new routes that link Hamburg to financial centres including Milan and Copenhagen, the executive said.

"There is great potential to stimulate the demand and increase the traffic," Mr Haagensen said. "Our objective is not to steal market share from anyone." - Bloomberg

site_title: Samsung's 'floating facility' is world's largest vessel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Samsung's 'floating facility' is world's largest vessel

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SEOUL] South Korean shipbuilder Samsung Heavy Industries has floated a tanker-shaped vessel tagged as the world's largest "floating facility" with a length greater than the height of the Empire State Building in New York.

A Samsung spokeswoman said yesterday that the 488-metre long floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) platform - named "Prelude" - was set in the water at its southern shipyard in Geoje on Nov 30.

The vessel cannot be described as a "ship" because it is unable to move under its own steam and must be towed.

But its specifications are impressive.

Once completed, the facility will weigh more than 600,000 tonnes fully loaded, displacing the same amount of water as six of the world's largest aircraft carriers.

Measuring 74 metres wide and 110 metres high, it is expected to produce 3.6 million tonnes of LNG a year and its storage tanks have a capacity equivalent to approximately 175 Olympic swimming pools.

Commissioned by the Dutch energy giant Shell, the facility is due to be delivered by September 2016.

In a press release on its website, Shell said Prelude would operate in a remote basin around 475 km north-east of Broome, a town in Western Australia, for about 25 years.

It is an all-weather facility designed to withstand the most powerful category five cyclone. - AFP

site_title: Compassionate look at tenants' struggles
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Compassionate look at tenants' struggles

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

OLIVER Chong made a splash in the theatre scene this year when his Mandarin play Roots scooped the Best Script and Production Of The Year awards at the Life! Theatre Awards.

The one-man play tells the real-life story of Chong's search for his family's ancestry in China. Although the production was very small, the story had a humanity and universality that transcended its production scale.

It is with high expectations then that audiences watched Chong's new Mandarin play Citizen Pig last weekend, a collaboration with fellow writer-director-actor Liu Xiaoyi and staged by the Finger Players. Like Roots, Citizen Pig also employs gentle humour and pathos as it depicts the real-life struggles of Singapore tenants at the hands of mercenary landlords.

Chong and Liu took on multiple characters to relate how they were separately duped into renting spaces that either didn't belong to the landlord or had already been rented to other parties.

Their subsequent attempts to seek legal recourse proved futile as the legal cards were largely stacked against them.

The point that both men make is that, however "fair" Singapore makes out its system to be, it still favours the rich and penalises the rest. Legal services, for one, come at such exorbitant costs that the average Singaporean has to think twice about before seeking. Using a minimalist stage design once again, Chong together with Liu have managed to craft a clear and concise story that would resonate with most ordinary Singaporeans.

And though, admittedly, Citizen Pig does not have the far-reaching universality that Roots has - not because of the subject but its narrower treatment of the subject - it is still a heartfelt, humanistic work.

site_title: Do the London arts hop
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Do the London arts hop

From Japanese erotica circa 1600 to edgy street art, arts lovers headed for London this Christmas season will have their stockings full, writes HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

The Drowned Man

Temple Studios, 31 London Street, W2 1DJ

From now till Feb 2014 at various times

Tickets from

nationaltheatre.org.uk

IN the 20-odd years that this writer has been watching theatre, he has never experienced anything quite as dreamy, mysterious and expansive as The Drowned Man by theatre troupe Punchdrunk.

The play is staged in a disused building near Paddington station in Central London. The entire four storeys have been converted into a dramatically-lit Hollywood movie studio where a story of ambition and murder unfolds.

But you won't be told the story in a straightforward fashion. And you won't really get to sit down and watch it either. You are made to wear a masquerade ball mask, cut yourself off from your companions (unless you choose to stay with them), explore the space on your own, and piece the narrative together.

In every room, painstakingly designed to evoke a certain bygone era, a set of actors play out hypnotic scenarios that ranges from the funny to the tragic to the flat-out creepy. Together, they tell the story of a young actor and actress who are willing to sacrifice everything - including their marriage - for a slice of Hollywood stardom.

You find yourself moving from room to room, almost in a daze, as the action takes place around you. Sometimes, if you're lucky, they burst into beautifully choreographed dance routines just inches from you. And because you're watching a live show in a movie studio setting, the lines between the actual and illusory, the story and the story they're filming, become very blurred.

Yet despite the fragmented nature of the scenes, the production is structured so ingeniously that you find yourself converging with other audiences for the play's stunning finale.

If you're looking for a stage production that gives you real bang for your buck, The Drowned Man would be it: for its standard ticket price of £47.50 (S$98), you get to watch all the action up close - instead of somewhere up in the circles had you opted for a similar-priced ticket to a hit musical.

content:

Swissco beefing up fleet with $42m orders

Cosco bags $54m contract from Asian buyer

Published

Wed, Dec 4, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SWISSCO Holdings has placed orders to add $42 million worth of vessels to its fleet, while Cosco Corporation has secured a US$54 million contract.

Swissco's orders are for two anchor handling tug supply vessels and a fast utility/crewboat with a one plus one option.

The newbuild vessels, excluding owner supplied equipment, are worth an aggregate of $42 million.

The vessels will be built in Chinese yards and are expected to be delivered in 2015.

Swissco said that renewing its fleet to maintain a low age profile is part of the group's overall strategy to stay competitive.

As at end-November, Swissco had 32 vessels in its fleet, and 14 under construction.

Executive chairman Robert Chua said: "We believe that the heightened demand for offshore support vessels will remain sustainable on the back of healthy level of activities in the robust oil and gas industry and we will continue to tap on this growing demand by enhancing our fleet capabilities through our vessel expansion and fleet renewal programme."

Separately, Cosco - through Cosco (Zhoushan) Shipyard Co Ltd - has clinched a US$54 million contract from an Asian buyer to build two 64,000 DWT bulk carriers.

Cosco (Zhoushan) Shipyard is a subsidiary of the company's 51 per cent owned subsidiary, Cosco Shipyard Group.

The bulk carriers are scheduled for delivery in the fourth quarter of 2014.

The contract is not expected to have a material impact on the net tangible assets and earnings per share of the company for the year ending Dec 31, 2013.

Shares of Cosco and Swissco finished unchanged at 72 cents and 30.5 cents, respectively, yesterday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Wines for early drinking

Young wines present a taste profile that can offer up surprises, writes NK YONG

Listen to this article

Published Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

LOOKING for a reasonably mature wine to drink with dinner, I came across my last bottle of Cims de Porrerra Classic 1996. At 17 years of age it should be quite mature. It had been some time since I last drank one and it would be interesting to see how this 1996, the first vintage of Cims had matured. It was very enjoyable, its colour showing just a tinge of brown against a deep red.

There was an aroma of fresh ripe fruit, and the palate showed surprisingly good freshness and the taste of well-ripened fruit. The wine was full and lush, without much tannin. I thought had begun to lose some of its fruit, though, and true enough the next day the thinness of the palate confirmed this. This was the last of a case of 12, bought locally in June 1999, soon after release at $73 per bottle, not exactly modest in price.

Bodega Cims de Porrerra was founded in 1996 as a joint venture between Jose Louis Perez Verdu, Llis Llach the musician and the Porrera Cooperative. The winemaker was Sarah Perez, Jose Louis's daughter.

site_title: Airbus plans to add more seats to A340
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airbus plans to add more seats to A340

It will also cut maintenance costs in bid to boost jet's market value

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[TOULOUSE] Airbus plans to lift the seat count on the A340 wide-body jet and cut maintenance costs in an effort to prop up the market value for its longest aircraft, which went out of production two years ago after slack sales.

The plan, which needs approval from regulators, would see the seat count on the twin-aisle airliner go to 475, according to a presentation by Airbus and engine makers, in London on Wednesday, to A340 owners. Service costs on the four-engine jet would fall to the equivalent of two powerplants to improve its economics.

Airbus stopped building the plane in November 2011 after customers picked up more fuel-efficient two-engine models such as Boeing's 777 and the shorter Airbus A330. Adding more seats would underpin Airbus's efforts to bolster the A340's value in the secondary market as operators renew their fleets.

"This will revolutionise A340 economics," Airbus chief operating officer John Leahy said in a e-mail following the presentation, where engine makers Rolls Royce and CFM International, a joint venture of General Electric and Safran, also spoke to a group of about 100 people with an interest in A340 values.

The new high-density version of the A340 would compare to the A340-600 that can seat 359 in a two-class layout. The A340 can seat nine abreast in seats 16.7 inches wide, said the Toulouse, France-based aircraft maker, which has been publicly pushing for an 18-inch seat standard for long-range planes.

The 8 per cent increase in capacity would translate to a potential US$5.5 million in extra revenue per year, according to the presentation at the London gathering, which sought to assure A340 customers of the residual value of their asset.

The extra seat count would bring the A340 close to the capacity of the largest four-engine aircraft, the Boeing 747 jumbo and the A380 double-decker. A handful of airlines have also boosted jet capacity, and operating economics, by cramming large numbers of economy seats onto existing air frames.

Demand for the A340 shrank after large twin-engine models such as Boeing's 777 won regulatory approval for the long over-water flights that were once the domain of four-engine planes. Airbus built 377 A340s, of which 359 remained in operation at the end of October.

Lufthansa, Europe's second largest carrier, is the biggest operator of the A340, with 48 still in service. The German airline said that it plans to fly the aircraft for some time, and that the residual value is irrelevant for the airline.

CFM makes the turbines for the A340-300 with Rolls-Royce as the sole powerplant provider for the larger A340-500 and -600 models.

Rolls-Royce may ease the terms of long-term maintenance agreements that it calls TotalCare to better suit second-hand operators. Leased engines may also be provided, said the London-based company, which operates a small turbine leasing unit. - Bloomberg

Hapag-Lloyd, CSAV mull merger options

Global trade slump sparks move to court Chilean firm

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[HAMBURG] Hapag-Lloyd AG is discussing a possible merger with Cia Sud Americana de Vapores SA (CSAV), Latin America's biggest container shipping line, as the companies struggle to overcome a global trade slump that has left the industry in crisis.

The talks are focused on whether "a possible business combination or any other form of association would be of mutual interest", Hamburg-based Hapag-Lloyd said in a statement yesterday.

Hapag-Lloyd, the biggest German container line with a fleet of 152 vessels, is still reeling from the slump triggered by the 2008 collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings, reporting a 64 per cent decline in profit for the third quarter, its peak season.

It's turning its sights to CSAV after talks to merge with local competitor Hamburg Sued, owned by family-owned German holding company Oetker-Group, failed in March because shareholders of both companies couldn't agree on terms.

The talks with Valparaiso, Chile-based CSAV "have not resulted in any binding or non-binding agreement between the parties", Hapag-Lloyd said in the statement, without elaborating further.

CSAV surged 13 per cent, the most in more than a year, after Die Welt newspaper reported on Wednesday night that the Latin American container shipper is negotiating a merger with its German rival.

CSAV's 86 per cent loss in the past three years is the worst performance among peers tracked by Bloomberg. In response to a glut of new vessels, operators such as AP Moeller-Maersk A/S are forming alliances with competitors to lower costs and eliminate excess capacity on trade routes.

The billionaire Luksic family controls CSAV with a 46 per cent stake. The Luksic's holding company Quinenco SA has put more than US$1 billion into CSAV in the past two years after the company lost a record US$1.25 billion in 2011.

Top executives of Hapag-Lloyd and CSAV last month met in Miami to discuss a possible merger, Die Welt reported on its website, without saying where it got the information.

Hapag-Lloyd is owned by a group of shareholders including German tourism company TUI AG, HSH Nordbank AG and the city of Hamburg. TUI, which holds a 22 per cent stake, has endorsed an initial public offering of the shipping company.

CEO Friedrich Joussen on Nov 7 said he doesn't expect an exit through an IPO before Hapag-Lloyd's Rolf Habben-Jansen replaces current CEO Michael Behrendt next July.

Hapag-Lloyd formed an alliance in Asia-Europe trade, called G6, in March 2012. The other partners are APL, Hyundai Merchant Marine, Mitsui OSK Lines, Nippon Yusen Kaisha and Orient Overseas Container Line. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore is 9th most expensive Asian city

Shifts in ranking in cost-of-living survey mainly due to currency movements

Published

Thu, Dec 5, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Republic has slipped one spot to become the ninth most expensive Asian city for expatriates, marking the first time since 2010 that it has fallen behind Hong Kong in eighth position.

ECA International, which undertakes this biannual cost-of-living survey, said this was largely due to the recent weakening of the Singapore dollar against the US dollar, to which the Hong Kong currency is pegged.

Its Asia regional director Lee Quane told The Business Times: "Singapore has been leapfrogged by Hong Kong mainly because of currency movements. We collect our data in local currency, but for the purposes of the rankings, we convert all prices to USD.

"Regionally, Singapore may be down one spot, but that doesn't indicate that prices have fallen. On the contrary, prices here have risen by about 3 per cent in comparison to the previous year."

Prices elsewhere - China and Hong Kong, for instance - were up one per cent over the year, but Mr Quane stressed that the Republic was "still considered competitive".

Inflation rates in Indonesia and India are more than 8 per cent, "so we still see that Singapore, relative to other competing locations in the region, is cheaper".

He pointed out that Singapore is still less expensive than Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul - major developed locations that compete with it for talent and for foreign investment.

"So Singapore does remain relatively competitive, I think."

Globally, Singapore inched up one place to become the 30th-most expensive location worldwide for expatriates.

Mr Quane said: "Again, this is all due to relative movements. Locations which were previously ranked as being more expensive than Singapore have now fallen in our rankings. The Australian dollar, for example, has depreciated against the USD by approximately 15 per cent, so places like Sydney, Melbourne and Perth have all fallen below Singapore this time."

The top three most expensive cities are Caracas, Luanda and Oslo, in that order; Manhattan was ranked 33rd.

The survey, conducted to help companies calculate the remuneration packages for employees being sent on overseas assignments, compares a basket of like-for-like consumer goods and services commonly bought by expatriates in 440 locations worldwide.

Since accommodation rentals, car purchases and school fees are typically compensated for in a separate benefits package, ECA International's survey does not take such items of expenditure into account.

Even if it does, Mr Quane said he does not think Singapore's regional ranking would shift substantially.

He expects Singapore to remain in the top 10 most expensive locations in the region in the years to come.

site_title: Bank fines till 2012 add up to £148b: study
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bank fines till 2012 add up to £148b: study

Published

Wed, Dec 4, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE cost of bank misdeeds and poor conduct has multiplied to levels comparable to gross domestic products of Singapore, Greece and several other nations.

Between 2008 and the end of 2012 ten leading banks had to pay £148 billion (S$304 billion) in fines and provisions for extra litigation and penalties, according to a study of the London School of Economics.

The size of payments and fines will increase further this year because of scandals relating to the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor), mis-sold products and allegations into foreign exchange manipulation.

Yesterday EU antitrust regulators fined six financial institutions including Deutsche Bank, Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup a record total of 1.71 billion euros (S$2.9 billion) for rigging financial benchmarks.

The penalty is the biggest yet to be handed down to banks for rigging the benchmarks used to determine the cost of lending, one of the most brazen violations of conduct since the financial crisis.

It is also the highest antitrust penalty ever imposed by the commission, the EU's competition regulator.

The other banks penalised are Societe Generale, JPMorgan and brokerage RP Martin. Deutsche Bank received the biggest fine of 725.36 million euros.

The European Commission said it would continue to investigate Credit Agricole, HSBC, JPMorgan and brokerage ICAP for similar offences.

Roger McCormick, who is a former partner with City law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, is leading a team of seven in the Conduct Costs Project of the London School of Economics.

So far, the calculations from regulator and bank reports, legal and other public information has involved only ten banks which were given the opportunity to assess and comment on the calculations.

The budget from the UK Higher Education Innovation Fund was a shoestring £37,000, but Prof McCormick wants to broaden the study to include a larger number.

The aim is to keep it rolling over for a five-year period and possibly include other costs, for example, rogue trader losses which are generally the result of poor compliance and management.

Bank of America has paid the price for being the "worst offender" and has had to fork out £30.4 billion.

Including provisions for future costs, amounting to £23.6 billion, the total expense between 2008 and end 2012 is calculated at a whopping £54 billion.

JP Morgan, which recently received considerable publicity over a settlement of US$13 billion, had total costs of £24.7 billion at the end of 2012 and UBS a similar amount.

Lloyds Banking Group heads UK banks with conduct costs of £9.24 billion followed by HSBC at £6.3 billion and Barclays, £5.1 billion.

Standard Chartered is not included but it made a settlement of US$667 million with the US authorities for alleged unacceptable finance and relationships, notably entities in Iran.

"The fundamental question is whether these costs will start going down soon, if these banks now have sound ethical cultures? If not, why not?," asks Prof McCormick.

"Banks are required by regulators to 'know your customer', but do we know as much as we should about them?"

"Despite ongoing scandals, they say they are, at last, trying to be more ethical than in the past and determined to restore public trust. How can we test that? Is it just the latest PR message or is there some substance to it?"

Prof McCormick advises customers to change banks if they do not perform as promised even though it could be a time consuming administrative hassle to move.

site_title: Blackstone builds its warehouse arm cheaply
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blackstone builds its warehouse arm cheaply

It's assembled what is 'basically a simple, high-quality national industrial portfolio'

Published

Wed, Dec 4, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[CHICAGO] Blackstone Group LP is in the spotlight as it prepares a record stock offering for the Hilton hotels chain. Its success building one of the nation's biggest warehouse landlords has garnered far less attention.

IndCor Properties Inc, the Chicago-based industrial real estate company that Blackstone formed in 2010, has more than doubled in size since its inception and continues to make acquisitions. Demand for US warehouse space is outpacing construction, leading to higher lease rates and declining vacancies as spending by consumers and businesses recovers.

"It's an essential part of the economy as we move goods around the country," Frank Cohen, Blackstone's senior managing director overseeing industrial investments, said in a telephone interview. "You don't just need it in New York or Los Angeles. You need toothpaste everywhere. The tile guy needs tiles, or plumbing supplies, everywhere."

Blackstone, the largest private-equity real estate firm, began buying industrial property in a depressed market, in many cases acquiring assets whose owners had purchased them close to the market's 2007 peak and were hurt by a plunge in values after the credit crisis. IndCor's crown jewel is 20 million square feet of warehouses, mainly in California, that it acquired from Walton Street Capital LLC by amassing positions in the underlying debt.

"Traditional, high-quality industrial has been very sought after by investors, so it was very hard for us to buy it prior to the market downturn," Mr Cohen said.

Investors of late have been focused on hotel, retail and rental-housing deals by Blackstone's real estate arm, a testament to the breadth of its property empire.

Its Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc, the world's largest hotel operator, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) of as much as US$2.4 billion, according to a regulatory filing on Monday. That would surpass Hyatt Hotels Corp's US$1.09 billion sale in November 2009 as the largest lodging IPO.

IndCor's holdings exceed 100 million sq ft. That makes it about the same size as the largest real estate investment trust (Reit) focused on US industrial properties: Indianapolis- based Duke Realty Corp, which has 121 million sq ft of distribution space in the nation and a US$4.9 billion market value.

The biggest warehouse Reit is San Francisco-based Prologis Inc, with 562 million sq ft in 21 countries, including about 280 million sq ft in the US.

"IndCor has been buying like crazy," said Rene Circ, director of industrial research at CoStar Group Inc's Property and Portfolio Research division in Chicago. "They've been focusing on large, large portfolios."

Mr Cohen declined to comment on whether Blackstone plans to sell IndCor or take it public.

The three-month rolling average price for industrial buildings peaked at US$78.60 per square foot in October 2007, and fell to a low of US$47.12 psf in November 2009, data from Real Capital Analytics Inc shows. Prices have since climbed to US$77.06 psf. Industrial-property purchases rose to almost US$32 billion from January through September, up from US$24 billion a year earlier, according to the New York- based research firm.

Two deals that kicked off IndCor, among 10 transactions Blackstone has made to build the company, were purchases from Eaton Vance Corp funds and Prologis totalling almost 41 million sq ft.

Blackstone typically looks for assets that need work to increase their value. The firm has acquired warehouses that have vacancies higher than the national average and are in key distribution markets, including smaller cities, said Tim Beaudin, IndCor's chief executive officer.

"With this recovering market we've had a lot of success," he said. Many of the properties were in need of increased leasing, capital investment and improved management, Mr Beaudin said. "We look for assets that need some tender, loving care."

Another purchase now part of IndCor's holdings was about 16.5 million sq ft acquired in stages from sellers including Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc and Prologis. Those transactions included Blackstone Real Estate Partners VII's acquisition of a Reno, Nevada, industrial portfolio for US$427 million in August.

The fund also has agreed to buy about 7 million sq ft from Pacific Life Insurance Co, including warehouses in Reno, in a deal of about US$320 million set for completion by the end of the year, said a person with knowledge of the agreement.

IndCor has increased occupancies in Reno, and rents are starting to rise, Mr Beaudin said.

"That market had been kind of beaten down," he said. "We see that market being very, very good to us."

The fundamentals of the US industrial market are likely to keep improving for the next 3-5 years, Mr Beaudin said. Internet stores such as Amazon.com Inc and traditional retailers are leasing more space in distribution centres, helping reduce vacancies.

Rising industrial production, increased trade and growing business inventories also have helped support demand for warehouse space, said Jared Sullivan, senior economist with CBRE Econometric Advisors, part of Los Angeles-based commercial-property brokerage CBRE Group Inc.

"That's why people are excited about industrial real estate right now," Mr Sullivan said. "The seeds are there for continued strength in the sector."

Also helping industrial owners such as Blackstone is a decline in warehouse and distribution-centre construction. About 59 million sq ft of industrial real estate will be added in the US this year, down from the pre-recession average of about 150 million sq ft annually, according to CBRE.

"We'll build as many industrial warehouses this year in the US as were built in 1955," Mr Cohen said.

Industrial availability in US metropolitan areas fell to 11.7 per cent in the third quarter from 13 per cent a year earlier, data from CBRE shows. Warehouse landlords have had 12 consecutive quarters of net occupancy gains, starting in the fourth quarter of 2010, according to Reis Inc, a New York-based real estate research firm.

Industrial rents will climb 4.4 per cent next year and 4.6 per cent in 2015, according to a CBRE forecast. The availability rate probably will fall to 11.2 per cent next year, and 11.1 per cent by the end of 2015, the firm said.

Rental growth this year is projected to outpace inflation for the first time since 2006. CoStar expects rents to continue gaining and return to pre-recession highs by the first half of 2016, Mr Circ said.

"Rents are definitely still on the rise," he said. "We've had a decent year."

Rent and occupancy improvements have been a boon for warehouse landlords. A Bloomberg index of seven industrial Reits has returned 8.6 per cent including reinvested dividends this year, making it the third-best performer among Reits, after hotels and self-storage. First Industrial Realty Trust Inc, a Chicago-based company with 62.5 million sq ft of space in 25 states, is the best performer in the warehouse index this year, rising 22 per cent through Monday.

Prices for warehouses are increasing as well. The three-month rolling average capitalisation rate for US industrial property was 7.6 per cent in October, compared with a high of 9.2 per cent four years earlier, according to Real Capital Analytics. (A measure of yield, cap rates fall as prices rise.)

Investing in industrial real estate isn't risk-free. A slowdown in the global economy, hurting worldwide trade, would cut demand for US warehouse and distribution-centre space, said Craig Guttenplan, a Reit analyst at CreditSights Inc in London. Absent such a decline, IndCor may find it difficult to keep expanding as rents and occupancies rise.

"There are still some interesting opportunities out there - just not as many as in the last few years," Mr Cohen said.

It may still be a year or two before the industrial properties' performance is improved and Blackstone begins to decide how to exit the IndCor investment, either by taking the company public or through a sale, Mr Beaudin said. Blackstone is "still trying to stabilise what we have", he said.

"There seems to be, among the people who invest in this asset class, excitement about the possibility" of an IPO, Mr Cohen said. "What we've assembled is basically a really simple, high-quality national industrial portfolio." - Bloomberg

site_title: Airfreight market on recovery path with Oct traffic up 4%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airfreight market on recovery path with Oct traffic up 4%

Load factors show signs of bottoming out after a year of declines: Iata

Published

Wed, Dec 4, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The global air cargo market continues gradual recovery with the industry posting 4 per cent year-on-year growth in traffic in October, as most regions registered an expansion thanks to an improving business environment.

Global capacity was up 4.9 per cent, which caused freight load factor to come in at 46.4 per cent, according to a report by the International Air Transport Association (Iata). However, load factors are showing signs of bottoming out after a year of continued decline, Iata noted.

The airfreight market was also stronger in October compared to the month before, when traffic contracted 0.3 per cent.

Performance differed among the regions in October, though Africa was the only one to experience a decline.

Asia-Pacific carriers, which account for nearly 40 per cent of global cargo traffic, rebounded with volumes increasing by 2 per cent in October after posting year-on-year declines throughout 2013. However, this was outstripped by a 4.1 per cent bump in capacity, resulting in a load factor of 56.2 per cent.

The expansion in cargo traffic in the region came on the back of a pick-up in regional trade as a result of a stronger Chinese economy, where manufacturing activity hit a seven-month high during the month.

Iata noted that both export and import volumes in emerging markets in Asia were up, vis-a-vis a decline in the middle of the year, which "bodes well" for further growth in coming months.

Middle Eastern carriers chalked up double-digit growth of 12.3 per cent, after slowing in September because of Ramadan. Capacity was just slightly under, growing at 12.1 per cent, while cargo load factor worked out to 45.4 per cent.

Meanwhile, European and North American airlines saw growth of 4.4 per cent and 3.7 per cent respectively. In Europe, the recovery is fragile, given that Q3 growth slowed to 0.1 per cent from 0.3 per cent in Q2, Iata said, adding that weak growth for the rest of the year should result in "further modest expansion" in European freight traffic.

In Africa, traffic was down 2.7 per cent compared with a year ago, continuing a trend seen for several months. While trade volumes in Africa are rising, competition on key trade routes is stiff, and the insufficient infrastructure and political stability remain challenges.

Tony Tyler, Iata's director-general, said: "Since mid-year, we have seen modest but sustained growth in cargo fed by stronger business confidence and improving trade flows. Air cargo is still a very tough business. Matching capacity to demand has been difficult in an environment where passenger traffic is growing more robustly. There is some evidence that the fall in load factors has stabilised, but yields remain under pressure."
